ElementSection.text: To assist the reintegration of retunring refugees UNHCR will construct new healthcare centres and rehabilitate damaged ones.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of health facilities equipped/constructed/rehabilitated Changed

Cause.name: Healthcare facilities inadequate

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Health services in Afghanistan are poor. Returnees face the same difficulties, if not worse, as the general population in terms of health services and facilities provided in the country. Returnees have access to health services as the population at large (some 80%). However, these services are often inadequate and not easily accessible in rural areas where the majority of persons of concern settle upon repatriation.

UNHCR, through partners, provides basic health services for returnees at the Encashment Centers upon their return in the country. All minimum costs related to this activity will be within the Operating Level. In order to support the reintegration of the Afghan returnees, upgrade or construction of health facilities in the return areas is required. The cost for reaching this objective will be above the Operating Level.

Indicator.name: Extent persons of concern have access to primary health care

ElementSection.text: New schools will be constructed for return villages.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of educational facilities constructed and accessible for children with disabilities

Cause.name: Education facilities damaged or destroyed

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Indicators on education remain amongst the worst in the world. Afghan girls in particular face alarming challenges in accessing education. There is a gap in capacity of the Government of Afghanistan (about 50% of children of school age are enrolled) to construct new schools as well as equip them. There is critical shortage of female teachers including shortage of properly trained teachers in general.

As part of the comprehensive reintegration approach, UNHCR will evaluate the need for upgrade of the existing of education facilities or even their construction in certain cases, in close collaboration with relevant national authorities. In order to provide a complete assistance programme aspiring towards the reintegration of returnees, UNHCR will assess and respond to the education gaps. The construction/upgrade of 15 schools on reintegration model sites is envisaged. Close cooperation and coordination will be maintained with UNICEF.

Southeastern Region completed equipping the Library and Conference Hall of Paktya University, Southeastern Region of one girls secondary school for 4,016 returnees. Awareness training on the importance of education for the parents and raising on usage and protection of public infrastructure for school students for 739 returnees is on-going, whilst providing social and recreational support for schools and youth is planned, all in the Northern region. Finally one school with 8 classrooms is under construction in the Western region. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions (government and agencies) and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions where there are other actors whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Therefore, those objectives that have been prioritized relate to provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs and shelter assistance. With regard to health, WASH, livelihoods and education, objectives relating to referral mechanisms are prioritized.

Indicator.name: % of persons of concern aged 6-13 yrs enrolled in primary education

ElementSection.text: Returniing refugees lack basic household items. UNHCR will provide them with family NFI kits.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of household goods provided

Cause.name: Population unable to afford basic items

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: A large percentage of returnee families (around 68%) of the returnee population group are in need of basic household and hygiene items upon repatriation, during the period of time until they actually have access to reintegration assistance. This is particularly the case for vulnerable families who arrive to Afghanistan often with little or practically no household items.

It is planned to procure NFIs packages to cover the needs of some 30,000 vulnerable returnee families. Individual assessment will be carried out by UNHCR Sub-Offices and implementing partners. Basic NFIs will be delivered to these families.

Procurement of core NFIs and distribution of these items will be carried out during the course of 2012. Within the Operating Level it is envisaged the acquirement of family14,000 packages each containing 6 blankets, 2 jerry cans, 2 tarpaulins, 1 kitchen set. In addition, 1,000 tents will be procured to improve the response capacity to the needs of this PPG.

ElementSection.text: Construction of new shelters will support the integration of returnees.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level
ElementSection.text: Due to additional materials left over in Jalalabad, an additional 130 shelter were possible with a recalculation of locally procured items to maximise whole shelters provided in Jalalabad.

Indicator.name: # of long-term/permanent shelters provided

Cause.name: Housing damaged or destroyed
Population lacks land to build shelter

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text:
Lack of shelter remains one of the main challenges for the returnees throughout Afghanistan. UNHCR has been providing returnees with shelters since 2002. However, there is a large backlog of returnees that have not been assisted in addition to the returnees from the most recent years. It is estimated that about 68% (almost 68,000 families) of returnees do not have their own shelter. Most of them are staying with relatives and friends and, on average of three families share one dwelling. A large percentage of returnees also do not have land on which to build a shelter, this is mainly due to the increase in the number of families due to decades of exile.
Other basic infrastructure such as roads, bridges and irrigation are in dire need of repair and new ones are required. While there are a number of infrastructure projects being implemented in the country, there have been long delays due to security problems, incompetence and corruption.

One of the major concerns of the Afghan returnees is lack of shelter. Meeting this need requires a large amount of resources, which the returnee families usually do not have. The shelter programme will be implemented as part of a reintegration package. UNHCR through its implementing partners will consider the needs for shelter in conjunction with other support in the field of income generation/livelihood, health or education thus aiming to engage in an integrated approach to reintegration. In addition, UNHCR will consider compelling shelter needs in location other than the pilot sites. The total number of shelters in 2013 will be 6,000.

1,343 shelter are planned for refugee returnees according to the following regional breakdown: 110 in Central and Central Highlands, 180 in Northern, 353 in Western, 400 in Southeastern, 50 in South and 250 in Eastern Regions, but as yet not completed. Infrastructure is also on-going, with projects ranging from Cash For Work road rehabilitation or village access road creation, inlcuding ditches, to flood protection walls, small bridges, to the construction of one community centre in Kunduz, Northern Region. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions (government and agencies) and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions where there are other actors whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Therefore, those objectives that have been prioritized relate to provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs and shelter assistance. With regard to health, WASH, livelihoods and education, objectives relating to referral mechanisms are prioritized.
500 shelters will be constructed.

ElementSection.text: Water remains one of the main obtacicles for reintegration of returnees. UNHCR will support construction of new wells as well as rehabilitation of existing ones.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of PoC served by water system

Cause.name: Water systems damaged or destroyed

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: The water resources in Afghanistan are quite limited. It is estimated that less than 25% of the entire population has access to safe drinking water. This is also applicable to the returnee population. Again, returnees to both rural and remote and overcrowded urban areas do not have access to sufficient safe drinking water. In rural areas, a large majority drink water from unclean sources such as unprotected springs, uncovered shallow wells, canals, rivers and streams.

Water is one of the major challenges for the Afghan population. Access to potable water in certain areas is an impediment to the sustainability of return and reintegration. UNHCR can contribute to this need. The Government and other relevant actors are expected to substantially attend to this important need of the persons of concern. Water points in return villages/sites, including LASs (Land Allocation Schemes) as appropriate will be taken into consideration as part of the reintegration package. It is planned to construct some 500 water points for about 125,000 beneficiaries

11,635 water projects have been completed to-date, ranging from deep, tube and bore wells, to the extension of existing reservoirs and the rehabilitation of irrigation canals. 1,343 shelter are planned for refugee returnees according to the following regional breakdown: 110 in Central and Central Highlands, 180 in Northern, 353 in Western, 400 in Southeastern, 50 in South and 250 in Eastern Regions, but as yet not completed. Infrastructure is also on-going, with projects ranging from Cash For Work road rehabilitation or village access road creation, inlcuding ditches, to flood protection walls, small bridges, to the construction of one community centre in Kunduz, Northern Region. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions (government and agencies) and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions where there are other actors whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Therefore, those objectives that have been prioritized relate to provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs and shelter assistance. With regard to health, WASH, livelihoods and education, objectives relating to referral mechanisms are prioritized.
Some 83 wells will be constructed.

ElementSection.text: The abilities of the community to access employment will be enhanced by provision of vocational training courses.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of PoC provided with vocational training

Cause.name: Insufficient income to cover food and subsistence needs
Population lacks means of livelihood

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Obstacles to self-reliance are a challenge for the whole population and not a phenomenon only visible in the case of Afghan returnees. Scarce resources of the country make it difficult for the population to earn a steady income. Only about 10-15% of the population has access to different types of gainful employment). The lack of skills and employment opportunities add to the issues returnees face once they return to their places of origin.

Lack of livelihood and employment opportunities for the Afghan population in general and the returnees in particular will be the focus of the attention of the operation. Comprehensive support programmes intended to substantially improve the reintegration prospects of Afghan returnees will be developed and implemented in the regions where UNHCR has a presence and possibility to deliver, targeting the return populations

Small-scale vocational training programmes are currently being implemented in 7 locations targeting 465 returnees with identified opportunities and likelihood of success in existing markets, with a focus on women. Supported vocaional training ranges from handicrafts and marketing, computer skills, literacy courses, life skills, animal husbandry and general livestock management. All training is extended to the hosting community with up to 30% participantion, promoting peaceful co-existance. Cash For Work subsistance short-term projects range road rehabilitation or village access road creation, inlcuding ditches, to flood protection walls, small bridges, to the construction of one community centre in Kunduz, Northern Region. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions (government and agencies) and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions where there are other actors whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Therefore, those objectives that have been prioritized relate to provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs and shelter assistance. With regard to health, WASH, livelihoods and education, objectives relating to referral mechanisms are prioritized.
Only some 10% of the returnees in need of livelihoods will be assisted.

Indicator.name: % of persons of concern (18-59 yrs) earning at least minimum wages for more than 6 months per year

ElementSection.text: Reintegration of returning refugees will be assessed, results of which will be vital for better programming.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: Reintegration monitoring system established (yes/no)

Cause.name: Development actors insufficiently engaged in recovery and peace-building
Progress of reintegration will require continuous monitoring

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text:
Over 4.5 million of Afghan refugees returned to their home country with UNHCR assistance. Approximately over 1.1 million of them who repatriated as of 2006 started to face reintegration constraints. Complex social, economic, political and security factors present challenges for the reintegration of returnees. The return areas both rural and urban as well as the country as a whole lack the basic facilities and services to support the needs of the growing population particularly the returnees who are at a relatively disadvantaged position as compared to the local population. Further, economic and employment opportunities are scarce in many return areas particularly in rural and remote parts of the country, which makes return unsustainable and force families and individuals to move on to look for gainful employment in district and urban centres, including in country of asylum, to seek better economic opportunities.
Monitoring, profiling and assessment of level of reintegration of returning refugees need improvement so that their conditions are better understood, their needs are clearly identified and possible assistance programs are designed and implemented. It is assumed that approximately over 1.1 million of them who repatriated as of 2006 started to face reintegration constraints. While some regions in the country have been doing regular needs assessment and consistent return monitoring for several years, this has to be sustained and implemented throughout the country. UNHCR reintegration activities can only be truly effective if the reintegration programmes are specifically targeting the identified needs.

Relevant data on places of origin/destination of the Afghan returnees is generally available, as it is gathered upon their registration to return and upon repatriation through Encashment Centers. UNHCR and its partners will put more efforts in profiling the returnee population as well as assess their reintegration status. This information and data will be vital for the designing of assistance programs and their effectiveness.
Lack of access to certain areas of displacement compels UNHCR to provide its assistance through partners in addition engage others to monitor the implementation of the activities. Relevant costs will be budgeted under this Objective.
The remaining activity under this objective is the support to MoRR. UNHCR will provide technical expertise by employing specialists in particular fields, such as protection and income generation, areas in which the Ministry lacks capacity.

Returnee Monitoring has been conducted in different provinces and using mobile teams that could detect basic protection issues that could hinder integration (as lacking of documentation, no access to health services and education facilities) and suggest solutions in coordination with local authorities and agencies involved in development activities. The main issues affecting integration of returnees were considered the lack of shelters, lack of job opportunities and lack of health facilities. Following a series of discussions, a new returnee monitoring methodology and necessary tools were adopted in May 2013 and shared with the field offices for implementation. Under this monitoring methodology agreed by all sub/field offices returning families will be followed from the moment they arrive at the Encashment Center to their places of return/origin, with the aim to capture the challenges of reintegrating in Afghanistan. In addition a participatory need assessment will be conducted in the areas of high return particularly those not covered under the pilot reintegration areas. The needs assessment will target families who have returned to Afghanistan from the beginning of 2012 and will try to assess, based on the data of the VolRep database, the ratio of family who are no longer in the place of stated return, the number of family separated because of coping mechanism. This methodology will try thus to substantiate the anecdotal statement that 20% of the returned families engages in secondary displacement and seek to determine when families engage in secondary displacement.

Using the resources within the Operating Level, UNHCR expects to finalize the assessment of the extent of reintegration of returnees from the previous years and partly support remote monitoring arrangements.

ElementSection.text: Mobile clinics will assist the returnees to obtain legal documentation related to their land or civil status.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Cause.name: State system of justice lacks capacity

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Although efforts to strengthen the formal and informal justice system, fight corruption and incompetence have been on-going, it is the informal justice systems that most commonly resolve disputes. In general, access to either formal or informal justice system needs support in order to enable returnees to achieve solutions to their problems faced upon repatriation.

The rights of returnees are officially ensured in legislation and normative acts in place. However, their implementation is not always enabled accordingly. For example, land and property rights in Afghanistan are often subject to multiple claims which can take years to resolve, especially for families returning from many years in exile and whose homes are inhabited by others and whose land is used by others. In order to assist returnees to resolve their legal issues support will be provided by offering legal advice and representation. Awareness raising campaigns will be carried out by protection partners in the return areas as well as counseling will be available for individual cases.
Only 50% of the identified activities will be implemented.

ElementSection.text: UNHCR aims to strengthen the GVB prenventing mechanisms.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of advocacy interventions for women’s rights and gender equality conducted

Cause.name: Partner efforts not sufficiently coordinated
Traditional practices endanger women and girls

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Violence against women remains to be one of the most serious and deeply rooted protection concerns in Afghanistan. Although all women are affected, returnee girls and women, who may have adopted more progressive social norms while displaced, are at a greater risk. Social and economic independence for women are not accepted social patterns and participation in the political process is limited.

GBV in Afghanistan is one of the major issues with which girls and women are faced. UNHCR has cooperated in the past years with UNIFEM-UNWOMEN, the latter having a support system in place, including safe houses. UNHCR contributes to the overall programme, which cover the persons of concern to UNHCR. The same arrangement will continue during the course of 2013.

Since 2001, the Government of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan has taken important steps to improve the situation of women in the country, including the incorporation of international standards for the protection of women’s rights into national legislation. In this context the Government ratified in 2003 the Convention on Elimination of All forms of Violence against Women (CEDAW).The Constitution of Afghanistan guarantees equal rights to women and men. The Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS) focuses on elimination of gender discrimination against women, development of their human capital and ensuring their leadership to guarantee their full and equal participation in all aspects of life. But still women are facing problems for having access to their rights, such as right to education, work, employment, health and etcThrough its projects, UNHCR established women shuras in returnees and IDPs areas and built their capacity also in view of empowering women to take an informed decision on matters affecting their lives and the community.A big challenge remains the acceptance of female shura by male members of the community. Currently, there is a gap in communication between male and female shura, which still have a mere symbolic role within the community.

Indicator.name: Extent that known SGBV survivors receive support

ElementSection.text: Five encashment centres will be functional in 2013, namely in Kabul, Herat, Gardez, Jalalabad and Kandahar. The running costs of these centres will be covered fully. Assistance will be provided in the centres to Afghan returnees in the form of medical services, provision of cash grant, land mine awareness, immunization, and in some cases awareness raising on HIV, family planing and TB monitoring. Some of the families would require transit accommodation as their places of origin are considerably far from the centres.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text:
There are 1.7 million registered refugees in Pakistan and 1 million in Iran. The main constraint faced by Afghans upon return is the lack of absorption capacity in the country/place of return that could lead to problem of reintegration. Some of the factors that affect the absorption capacity include: difficult and deteriorating security situation that also disrupts development activities and provision of services; weak enforcement of law and justice system; lack of shelter and land for housing; small farm size and low agricultural productivity; lack of employment opportunities; low level of employable skills; lack and poor health and education facilities particularly for girls/women. Families with physically and mentally handicapped and elderly face extra vulnerability due to the lack of services and facilities that could support their needs and allow them being productive members of the society.
The “pull and push” factors in the country of asylum such as assistance programmes, availability of better social services and better employment, and harassment from police in Pakistan and Iran, increasing insecurity in the country particularly targeting the Afghans, increasing prices and cost of house rental, growing difficulties in getting employment due to economic environment, would affect the return process.
Reintegration of returning refugees requires an integrated and extensive approach while the needs are too large to be able to respond to with the limited resources allocated as well as the operational capacity of UNHCR. Cooperation with operational partners, donors and other UN agencies will be vital for a successful reintegration programme in Afghanistan

It is expected that the number of returnees in 2013 will remain relatively high provided that factors influencing the return trends will not undergo dramatic changes. A total of 172,000 individuals are expected to repatriate, including 150,000 from Pakistan, 20,000 from Iran and 2,000 from other countries. An average cash grant of USD 150 per person will be paid to individuals upon their return in Afghanistan. Other costs related to the functioning of the Encashment Centers and partners participating in the process will also be covered under this Objective.

A Trilateral meeting between Pakistan and Afghanistan Ministers for Refugees (SAFRON and MoRR) took place with UNHCR 28 June 2013. As a result, the key amendment to policy was the proposal for Proof of Registration cards to be extended up to 31 December 2015 (rather than 2014). Between 01 January and 22 June 2013 the recorded destinations of returning Afghans were to the Central Region (31%), mainly to the provinces of Kabul (22%), Logar (5%) Ghazni (2%) , Parwan(1%) and Wardak (1%), Eastern Region (22%) mainly to the provinces of Nangarhar (16%), Kunar (2%) and Laghman (3%), Northern and North-Eastern Regions (25%), mainly to the provinces of Kunduz (10%), Baghlan (6%) and Balkh (3%), Southern Region (10%) mainly to the provinces of Kandahar (6%) and Hilmand (3%) and Zabul (1%), Western Region (7%) mainly to the provinces of Hirat (5%) and Farah (1%).Five encashment centers continue to provide an average individual $150 grant, as well as assessing the voluntary nature of their repatriation, provide health, legal and social counseling as well as receiving information about mine and ordnance risks. An MoU is currently being drafted between the Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation and UNHCR. Also, a trilaterial agreement, including the relevant provincial departments, is inthe current final stages between the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation and UNHCR.

UNHCR Afghanistan plans to support the return of 67,000 Afghan returnees within the Operating Level of the total planned 162,000. All returning persons will benefit from the cash grant which covers their transportation cost from the country of asylum to their places or origin and partially assist them in managing their immediate needs upon return.

Indicator.name: % of persons of concern with intention to return who have returned voluntarily

ElementSection.text: During the period January-June 2013, a total of 25,858 Afghan refugees voluntary repatriated to Afghanistan among whom 20,856 came from Pakistan, 4,960 from Iran and 42 from non-neighboring countries. The return rate represents a 35% decrease compared to 2012. The current operating level available under Pillar one will facilitate a further 31,089 individuals to return in the remainder of 2013. A Trilateral meeting between the Governments of Pakistan and Afghanistan, and UNHCR took place on 28 June 2013 where the GoP provided information about its proposed national policy on Afghan refugees which includes the recommendation for the extension of the Proof of Registration cards until 31 December 2015, subject to the approval of its cabinet. Five Encashment Centers continue to provide an average individual 150 USD grant, provide health, legal and social counselling as well as information on mine and ordnance risks. A MoU is currently being drafted between the Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation and UNHCR. Also, a trilateral agreement, including the relevant provincial departments, is in the final stages between the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation and UNHCR.In line with the Solutions Strategy, UNHCR continued to pursue during 2013 a reintegration strategy aiming at facilitating the transition from humanitarian to development assistance. In this context, UNHCR has been working primarily with UNDP during 2013, in the framework of the Letter of Intent to which ILO and the Resident Coordinator are also parties, signed in February 2013. It was been agreed to revise the joint Voluntary Repatriation and Reintegration Project to include ILO and potentially other development partners. UNHCR is also actively engaged in the CCA/UNDAF process for 2014-2019 to ensure refugee returnees and internally displaced feature prominently in development priorities jointly identified by the UNCT. UNHCR has also been advocating with the Government to ensure returnee reintegration receives further political support and visibility. An agreement was reached with the 2nd Vice President of Afghanistan to create under his chairmanship an inter-ministerial committee to steer support for the achievement of solutions for returnees and IDPs to ensure their needs are taken into consideration in the national development plan. During the reporting period, UNHCR continued to focus its reintegration activities in 16 high return areas previously identified, in the context of the Solutions Strategy for Afghan Refugees. In the East. region, UNHCR undertook needs assessment in newly identified areas in order to accommodate new return trends and settlement locations. A participatory need assessment will be conducted in the areas of high return particularly those not covered under the pilot reintegration areas. This approach will be mainstreamed throughout the country for needs assessments in the current year for 2014 projects. 1,343 shelters are planned for refugee returnees in 2013 construction of which have started. Access to adequate shelter is a key determinant of initial reintegration for the returnees and hence a cornerstone of UNHCR’s reintegration strategy in Afghanistan. Infrastructure interventions implemented through short term Cash For Work (CFW) subsistence projects are also on-going. Infrastructure projects provide sustainability to the returnee and surrounding communities including access to services and livelihoods opportunities. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Therefore, those objectives that have been prioritized relate to shelter assistance, provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs.

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Unmet Needs (O)
ElementSection.text: • Challenges to a sustainable reintegration process remain vast and include insecurity and conflict, shortage of land, housing/shelter and livelihood opportunities. UNHCR alone will never be able to attain sustainable reintegration of the large number of returnees (5.7 million since 2002) in view of the lack of absorption capacity in the country. This is compounded by limited government capacity to provide infrastructure and deliver basic services, coupled with a significant “urbanization” of returnees, protection concerns (including gender inequalities), as well as frequent natural disasters. While the Solutions Strategy for Afghan Returnees have captured a portion of the needs to catalyse sustainable reintegration, the mobilization of development actors continues to remain a slow and challenging process. • The main issues affecting reintegration of returnees are lack of shelters, job opportunities, and access to basic facilities including health and education. 1,343 shelters are planned for refugee returnees in 2013 under the OL which is far below the comprehensive target of 6,065. UNHCR is currently reviewing the recommendation of the shelter evaluation carried out in 2012 (Maastricht University/Samuel Hall) in order to strengthen and improve, where feasible, specific areas of implementation in the current year (2013). Through the establishment of a Shelter Working Group in Kabul and the mission of the shelter specialist from UNHCR’s HQs in Geneva in May 2013, UNHCR is currently revising present guidelines in consultation with all relevant stakeholders (government and all shelter cluster members). However, as recommended by the Shelter specialist, a comprehensive review of the guidelines and implementation modalities may require the services of a dedicated consultant. • Urbanization of return and displacement remains a challenging issue, largely resulting from secondary displacement but are also part of the general urbanization phenomenon in the country. In this regard, the urban displaced populations may demonstrate mixed causes of displacement, including conflict / insecurity, natural disasters, economic hardship, etc. Therefore, it is difficult to categorize root cause of displacement. They may also be refugee returnees who were either displaced to urban centres or whom have migrated. In relation to urban displacement, the position of the Government is very restrictive in allowing international organizations to provide sustainable assistance due to fear that it will create a pull factor to the urban centres. • While the Government of Afghanistan has taken important steps to improve the situation of women in the country, including the incorporation of international standards for the protection of women’s rights into national legislation, women continue to face serious obstacles in accessing basic rights, including the right to education, work, employment, and health. While through its projects, UNHCR strives to address gender issues including SGBV, there are very limited funds to pursue any significant project given the tight earmarking to other sectors

ElementSection.sectionName: Assessment - Current Situation and Achievements to Date
ElementSection.text:
Afghan returnees
Since 2002, UNHCR has supported the voluntary repatriation of 4.6 million refugees, provided more than 217,000 returning refugees with shelters, supported more than 400,000 with either short-term cash assistance through cash for work projects or income-generation activities.
These types of assistance programmes have been in place since the beginning of repatriation in 2002 and always aimed at the most vulnerable families/individuals representing some 25 % of the total number of returnees of over 4.6 million whose repatriation was facilitated by UNHCR. The needs were much greater, particularly in the recent years, than the capacity of UNHCR and its partners to deliver. As a result, many Afghans have not been able to fully reintegrate and required more assistance to improve their living conditions, income opportunities and livelihoods.
The rights of returnees are officially ensured in legislation and normative acts. However, their implementation is not always enabled accordingly. For example, land and property rights in Afghanistan is often subject to multiple claims which can take years to resolve, especially for families returning from many years in exile and whose homes are inhabited by others. Afghanistan has layers of incompatible laws and regulations and various Presidential Decrees which result in a confusing myriad of competing obligations and rights. Further complicating the picture is the weakness of the formal justice system, which lacks adequate structures and trained legal professionals, especially in rural areas.
Based on assessments, experiences of the previous period of time and projected financial resources that may be made available, UNHCR concluded to place enhanced emphasis on monitoring of the returnees in the areas of origin/return to establish more reliable data to assess the extent of their reintegration that may eventually trigger adjustments of approaches, and to focus in the meantime on comprehensive reintegration assistance on a number of selected sites/communities.

UNHCR is closely coordinating its strategies and activities with regard to with the line ministry – MoRR, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other government departments. It will continue to build to the extent possible the capacity of MoRR which is yet to become adequate to the requirements of a comprehensive task to manage the populations of concern. UNHCR intends to provide support for improving MoRR’s management capacity concentrated focused on the following key areas: policy development, institutional strengthening, emergency response, playing its coordination role with other ministries.
The leadership of UNHCR in the Protection Cluster and the National IDP Task Force, as well as the Emergency Shelter and NFIs cluster gained momentum in 2011 and will be upheld to better coordinate the assessment of the needs of IDPs and provide adequate responses, as described in other parts of the COP.
As part of the UN Country Team, UNHCR will continue to play its part in urging greater coordination and technical and financial coherence with existing policies, programmes, and implementing arrangements. New approaches will be explored and implemented in terms of focusing a concerted action of the UN agencies with regard to reintegration and returnees on the basis of joint and coordinated assessment, planning and assistance, including UN programmes in pilot provinces.
UNHCR has a range of some 75 implementing partners, essentially government departments like MoRR/DoRRs and national and international NGOs, who are traditional partners working in the areas of repatriation, shelter, income generation, water, remote monitoring, legal information and assistance, delivery of NFIs, etc. The existing arrangements proved to be efficient in the past and will continue to be used in 2013. New partnerships primarily with UN agencies will be further developed in relation to joint programme and comprehensive reintegration activities on selected sites, communities and provinces.

ElementSection.sectionName: PPG Strategy - Protection and solution strategy (comprehensive)
ElementSection.text:
Afghan returnees
Office foresees the voluntary return of 172,000 refugees from neighboring countries, the overall majority - 150,000- from Pakistan, while 20,000 from Iran.
Families returning after decades in exile are likely to have many more family members, including the vulnerable elderly, adolescents that may have never been to their own country – therefore presenting adaptability challenges - and school-age children, including girls, who may face obstacles trying to access education in Afghanistan.
Returnees from a long-term in exile are therefore expected to look for re-integration alternatives in Afghanistan’s urban centers rather than opting to re-establish in their rural villages of origin.
Concerns remain over the current absorption capacity of the country, which remains severally strained. Through monitoring and the systematic identification of vulnerable returnee families in the Encashment Centers, the office intends to intervene and support cases facing special protection needs, with particular emphasis on families with children, female headed families and elderly returnees.
The landless status of many returnees, land and property rights disputes, the failures of the Government-led Land Allocation Scheme (LAS), the increasingly volatile security situation, the deterioration of the ongoing armed conflict and overall poverty prevailing in Afghanistan continue to prevent returnees from reintegrating in their places of origin.
Profiling exercises being implemented by UNHCR on areas of return will continue informing the Office and facilitating a better understanding of the current situation being faced by returnees in an IDP like situation, with particular emphasis to their protection needs.
This PPG includes in total 1,258,167 persons of concern.

Afghan returnees As explained at the Operation Plan level, UNHCR Afghanistan prioritized within the Operating Level only those activities that are related to the repatriation process for which the Office has mandate responsibilities, i.e. cash grant, functioning of the four Encashment Centers (ECs have been rationalized under the Operating Level pressure), protection monitoring in the areas of return to establish the extent of reintegration of the returnees form the previous years, and other protection activities that do not have associated operational costs.
The number of returnees has been prioritized to the level of 67,000 taking into account other correlating needs and with a view of eligibility requirements for cash grant. The allocations for activities such as the Encashment Centers (EC) and IPs operating in support of repatriation are made, as they need to be maintained irrespective of the number of returnees.
UNHCR Afghanistan also prioritized within the Operating Level the activities that require operational resources to intensify protection monitoring of non-integrated returnees with the aim to establish data related to the extent of their reintegration upon repatriation, in order to be able to provide targeted reintegration support outlined above the Operating Level.
The Objective “Potential for voluntary return realized” related to the GSP indicator “% of persons of concern with intention to return who have returned voluntarily” has been prioritized. It is expected that 100% of individuals concerned will return voluntarily.
The Objective “Risk of SGBV is reduced and quality of response improved” in relation to the GSP indicator “extent known SGBV survivors receive support” has also been prioritized but only from information sharing/advocacy perspective as in view of the Operating Level pressure. UNHCR will not be able to inject operational funds into project activities under this Objective.

Afghan returnees It is assumed that the repatriation operation will be implemented without major impediments provided that: (1) prevailing security situation in the neighboring countries and within Afghanistan will not create obstacles amounting to suspension of movements; (2) policies in neighboring countries with regard to the Afghan refugees will be adhered to as agreed upon in the framework of the Tripartite Commissions mechanism; (3) the Government of Afghanistan will continue to fulfill at least the basic minimum of its repatriation obligations and will not create bureaucratic obstacle, particularly in relation to UNHCR cooperation with DoRRs.
The hypothetical situation that would result in a massive influx of returnees into Afghanistan and/or large scale impossibility for the returning Afghans to reach their destination will be dealt with as an emergency.
Meeting reintegration needs of returnees on the basis of integrated approaches requires a confirmed buy-in by the Government and a fairly large spectrum of the UN and non-UN partners. It is assumed that this will be reasonably achieved in 2011 to pave the way for coherent cooperation in the planning year to better address the reintegration needs on this PPG and in general joint UN projects in some areas of Afghanistan. Security considerations are always kept in mind hoping that they will permit planned activities in selected areas.
In the scenario of not fully achieving the required level of coordination and interaction with the others, UNHCR will have to further prioritize its contribution to maximize the impact on a smaller number of beneficiaries.
IDPs
It is hoped that the Government will take more prominent responsibility in Kabul and in the provinces to manage internal displacement on the basis of UNHCR advice and documentation developed and tailored to Afghanistan specifics, and will play more efficient coordinating role. Coordination support role of UNHCR with all actors concerned in the framework of the Protection Cluster and the National IDP Task Force will continue. OCHA and IOM together with the Government will lead responses with regard to displacement caused by natural disasters while UNHCR will discharge its protection lead responsibilities.
It is assumed that security constraints will permit to reach as many IDPs in need as possible, including though available remote management mechanisms and partners.
UNHCR plans to have sufficient amount of NFIs to meaningfully assist the conflict induced IDPs, including those requiring winterization support. In the case of mass displacement beyond available capacity will have to be addressed through the activation of emergency mechanisms.
Refugees and asylum seekers
It is expected that the number of PoC under this PPG will remain small. It does not seem realistic that the Government will be able to take over from UNHCR RSD and assistance. Therefore the office will continue to fulfill it role as in the previous years.
UNHCR plans, however, to start assisting the relevant Government departments in drafting national refugee legislation and undergo on-the-job training in refugee matters

Afghan returnees Coordination with relevant national authorities and a number of IPs essentially working at the Encashment Centers is very important as regards facilitated repatriation. It will be pursued on a routine basis. In addition, UNHCR will continue to enjoy close collaboration with WFP on the issue of food assistance on the basis of a MoU extended until 2013. Potential constraints may predominantly arise in relation to larger than planned scale of repatriation which may lead to resources limitations on the part of the partners and UNHCR, including for initial reintegration activities.
The Office coordination strategy in relation to returnees from the previous years will be heavily premised on ensuring the involvement of the Government, relevant UN agencies, NGO partners and donors to provide comprehensive reintegration assistance to the beneficiaries on a number of selected sites/communities and in a number of provinces for a joint UN intervention to achieve sustainability of the returns and stability in respective areas.
UNHCR will also use partnerships to monitor the return areas in order to better establish reintegration needs of those PoC who have not been able to fully reintegrate. The lack of commitment to these objectives on the part of the partners may represent an obstacle that would need to be overcome through additional negotiations.

ProblemObjective.problemName: Health status of the population is unsatisfactory or needs constant attention
ProblemObjective.objectiveName: Health status of the population improved

Output.name: Access to primary health care services provided or supported

BudgetLine.comment: Medical services/intervention for IDPs in the south, west, east and north

ElementSection.text: Health facilities will be constructed and rehabilitated in places of displacement and return.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of health facilities equipped/constructed/rehabilitated

Cause.name: Healthcare needs continuous effort

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Health services in Afghanistan are some of the poorest in the whole world. IDP returnees face the same difficulties, if not worse, as the general population in terms of health services and facilities provided in the country due to the disruption and/or destruction of the basic health services in the place of return.

UNHCR will provide support for IDPs by improving the capacity and services provided by the existing health facilities in the areas of displacement. This aims also to avoid overuse of facilities and services available for the hosting communities. The tangible support will be limited essentially in focusing on bridging acute gaps, given that other actors, including the government departments, have larger resources and expertise in this area. Cooperation with WHO and other partners operating in the field of health will be maintained and strengthened.
Return to places of origin, as the most favorable durable solution, will be supported through construction and rehabilitation of 5 health facilities.

Indicator.name: Extent persons of concern have access to primary health care

ProblemObjective.objectiveName: Population has optimal access to education

BudgetLine.comment: Educatin facilities for IDP ( constructioin of schools)

ElementSection.text: Schools will be constructed and rehabilitated in places of return.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of educational facilities constructed and accessible for children with disabilities

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Indicators on education remain amongst the worst in the world. Afghan girls in particular face alarming challenges in accessing education. There is a gap in capacity of the Government of Afghanistan (about 50% of children of school age are enrolled) to construct new schools as well as equip them. There is critical shortage of female teachers including shortage of properly trained teachers in general.

IDPs returning to their places or origin, in certain areas of the country, do not have access to education as schools have been damaged. Rehabilitation of 3 schools will allow children to follow classes.

Awareness training on the importance of education for the parents and raising on usage and protection of public infrastructure for school students, benefiting 102 IDPS. UNHCR as the co-lead agency of the Emergency Shelter and NFIs Cluster and Lead agency for the Protection Cluster continues to guide and coordinate the emergency response by partners working with IDPs. Therefore though this objective is a GSP, when it comes to IDP solutions UNHCR focuses on areas where we have an added value, and playing a catalytic role in identifying needs and community based responses ensuring the involvement of key stakeholders and promoting education throughout.

Indicator.name: % of persons of concern aged 6-13 yrs enrolled in primary education

ElementSection.text: Vulnerable IDP families require basic NFI assistance. This is particularly relevant for conflict induced IDPs who left their places of origin mostly leaving behind their belongings, as only an estimated 40% of IDPs posses some items.

IDPs are in need of basic domestic items as a result of their displacement. The security situation in the country remains precarious and more displacement in the future is expected. UNHCR plans to procure a stock of 10,000 NFI packs.
Basic domestic items will be provided to vulnerable IDP families, and it is planned to procure and distribute 5,000 NFI packages within the Operating Level.

ElementSection.text: Support will be provided to PWSN cases.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: A very high number of IDPs in Afghanistan as a result of their displacement end up without any community support and especially females heading household are in dire need for support. UNHCR through its partners will strive to find possible durable solutions for them when possible

A very high number of IDPs in Afghanistan as a result of their displacement end up without any community support and especially females heading household are in dire need for support. UNHCR through its partners will strive to find possible durable solutions for them when possible.
1,000 EVIs will be assisted.

Since beginning of the year till end of June, totally 776 cases of persons with specific needs including 453 males (58%) and 323 females (42%) have been identified and assessed. Following the assessments, out of them, 561 cases were considered under criteria and approved to receive assistance. The majority of them are Refugee returnees, following by IDPs. Out of 561 approved cases, 423 cases have already received assistances, of whom 112 cases received direct cash assistance while the rest have been assisted through referral to the network of service providers, consultation and follow up. So far, 111 cases have been successfully closed, while the rest are still under progress and further follow up will take place to ensure that the assistance could have address their urgent specific needs. Assisted people have highly appreciated the project and have found the impact of it quite obvious on their life and particularly on addressing their specific needs and their integration into the community. Meanwhile the project has had a positive impact on the level of coordination and response of different service providers in deferent provinces through the establishment of PSN networks and organization of coordination meetings amongst the social service providers that have come together in that network.
1,000 more EVI cases will be assisted if funds are made available.

ElementSection.text: Shelter assistance will be provided to IDPs in dislacement and upon return to places of origin.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of long-term/permanent shelters provided

Cause.name: Housing damaged or destroyed
Population lacks land to build shelter

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text:
As in many cases the displacement of PoC is prolonged and the living conditions precarious. IDP families need basic shelter. There is a need for UNHCR shelter intervention to assist the most vulnerable and, as the lead agency for the Shelter and NFIs Cluster, for continued coordination of shelter assistance provided by all actors in Afghanistan and advocacy for a standardized shelter package for all IDPs.
Other basic infrastructure such as roads, bridges and irrigation are in dire need of repair and new ones are required. While there are a number of infrastructure projects being implemented in the country, there have been long delays due to security problem, incompetence and corruption.

It is quite difficult to find durable solutions for IDPs because of their complex situation, particularly in the context of Afghanistan. In many cases, IDPs are forced to multiple displacements as security deteriorates and conflicts spread in new areas. After careful assessment of the conditions of the IDPs, UNHCR Afghanistan took the stand to ensure only minimum living conditions for this category of persons of concern. Firstly, displacement is not prolonged in many instances, and, secondly, that the displacement is of temporary nature. 1,500 shelters are expected to be constructed for the beneficiary families while in displacement and places of return, however the focus will be on supporting durable solution thus majority of the shelters will be provided to families returning to their places of origin. Furthermore main access roads to markets will be rehabilitated to assist the livelihood opportunities of the returnees communities.

1,350 shelters are planned in 2013, but not as yet completed for IDPs. Materials for 1,000 of which were procured in 2012, but given a number of facors, were delayed in completion. 25 infrastructure projects planned for IDPs and returnees and other population, including 3.5 KM of road rehabilitation. Therefore though this objective is a GSP, when it comes to IDP solutions UNHCR focuses on areas where we have an added value, and playing a catalytic role in identifying needs and community based responses ensuring the involvement of key stakeholders and promoting education throughout.

Indicator.name: % of households living in adequate dwellings

BudgetLine.comment: drilling and material cost of 9 semi deep wells

ElementSection.text: New wells and water schemes will be constructed and rehabilitated in places of displacement and return.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of PoC served by water system

Cause.name: Water systems damaged or destroyed

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Water sources in the country are scarce and potable water is a serious concern. It is estimated that less than 25% of the population has access to safe drinking water. IDPs face the same problems in relation to water access as the rest of the population. IDP returnees to both rural and remote and overcrowded urban areas do not have access to sufficient safe drinking water. In rural areas, a large majority drink water from unclean sources such as unprotected springs, uncovered shallow wells, canals, rivers and streams.

IDPs face difficulties in accessing water sources in their places of displacement. In many cases, an increase of the capacity of the existing sources is required. This often involves the security of the beneficiaries as the existing water sources are not sufficient to cater the needs of both the local communities and the IDPs, thus putting the IDPs in a risky situation and jeopardizing their relations with the host communities. UNHCR in cooperation and coordination with other operational partners will attempt reducing this gap by constructing about 250 water points for some 62,500 beneficiaries.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: IDPs and IDP returnees in the rural areas must increasingly adapt to the cash economy while those in the urban areas must adapt to the prevailing labor market. The situation of the displaced requires intervention in terms of their capability to generate income and reach acceptable levels of self-reliance.

Access to certain areas of the country where displacement has occurred or where the IDPs have settled temporary is very often limited thus impeding the reach of the IDP populations. Secondary or even multiple displacement of population affects directly the continuity of reintegration projects. As a result, the number of projects envisaged aiming at the reintegration of IDPs is low. One of the possible types of projects can be cash for work as they provide immediate employment and income. More substantive projects will be implemented in return areas thus directly supporting the durable solutions.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Insufficient information is available for IDPs mostly as a result of limited access to the displacement areas. Lack of data on the IDPs influences the provision of humanitarian assistance and provision of solutions to their situation.

UNHCR will further focus in 2013 on profiling the IDPs and assessing their needs in order to provide a harmonized assistance. This will facilitate the identification of the displacement causes thus making possible advocacy and conflict resolution efforts, and further designing of programmes with the emphasis on possible immediate assistance and durable solutions.

The PMT UNHCR developed further with the function of producing reports extracted from the data in the system. All kinds of reports can be produced, only limited to the actual data at hand.
Overall around 980 groups consist of 574,327 persons (89,530 families) of conflict-induced IDPs are recorded in the PTM. Only this year until end of June 93,368 individual conflict-induced IDPs newly recorded in the system, of which more than 59,000 persons displaced this year.
In the PMT detailed information about IDPs i.e. places of origin and displacement (where IDPs currently live), cause of displacement, demography, age, sex, ethnicity, protection concerns, vulnerability, assistance receive, and the solutions found is recorded.
During 2013 the software was revised in order to debug some of the issues raised during the implementation and installed in all of our sub-offices. One day training was conducted for all PMT focal points from the field. Based on the lessons learnt currently the questionnaire is being revised. In June 2013, a FICSS team conducted a successful mission, including field visits, reviewing all aspects of information management in Afghanistan operation. A debrief of initial findings in particular highlighted the need for a senior Information Management Officer in order to bridge the current gap between data and analysis, and allow for a more pragmatic use of the current data.

Indicator.name: % of IDPs for which sex and age disaggregated data is available

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Although efforts to strengthen the formal and informal justice system, fight corruption and incompetence have been on-going, it is the informal justice systems that most commonly resolve disputes.

The rights of IDPs are not clearly stipulated in existing laws in Afghanistan. Land and property rights in Afghanistan are often subject to multiple claims which can take years to resolve. The formal justice system is weak, as well as lacks adequate structures and trained legal professionals, especially in rural areas. Legal advice and representation will be offered to IDPs through NRC-administered Information Counseling and Legal Assistance (ICLA) programme.

Indicator.name: Extent persons of concern have access to effective legal remedies

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text:
The delivery of NFIs and shelter materials sometimes faces delay particularly at critical times of the year and in certain locations. Any delays contribute to the additional difficulties particularly the vulnerable returnees who are most in need of this basic assistance.
UNHCR together with its implementing partners need to build up sufficient procurement, transportation and delivery capacity for NFIs and shelter materials.

Delivery of basic domestic assistance, essentially NFIs (for some 40,000 families) and shelter materials for the beneficiaries (3,000 families) of the shelter programme belonging to this PPG will be ensured. UNHCR through its partners will provide transportation and distribution of goods to the beneficiaries.
NFIs and shelter materials will be delivered to only 30% of the beneficiaries with the current budget allocation.
