Traditional practices endanger women and girls

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Violence against women continues to remain one of the most serious and deeply rooted protection concerns in Afghanistan. Although all women are affected, IDP girls and women, who can not count on the previously existing community structures before the displacement, are at a greater risk. Social and economic independence for women are not accepted social patterns and participation in the political process is limited.

GBV in Afghanistan is one of the major issues with which girls and women are faced. IDPs make no exception. UNHCR has cooperated in the past years with UNIFEM-UNWOMEN, the latter having a support system in place including safe houses. UNHCR contributes to the overall program, beneficiaries include IDPs. The same arrangement will continue during the course of 2013.

Since 2001, the Government of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan has taken important steps to improve the situation of women in the country, including the incorporation of international standards for the protection of women’s rights into national legislation. In this context the Government ratified in 2003 the Convention on Elimination of All forms of Violence against Women (CEDAW).The Constitution of Afghanistan guarantees equal rights to women and men. The Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS) focuses on elimination of gender discrimination against women, development of their human capital and ensuring their leadership to guarantee their full and equal participation in all aspects of life. But still women are facing problems for having access to their rights, such as right to education, work, employment, health and etcThrough its projects, UNHCR established women shuras in returnees and IDPs areas and built their capacity also in view of empowering women to take an informed decision on matters affecting their lives and the community.A big challenge remains the acceptance of female shura by male members of the community. Currently, there is a gap in communication between male and female shura, which still have a mere symbolic role within the community.

Indicator.name: Extent that known SGBV survivors receive support

ElementSection.text:
The number of people recorded as conflict-induced displaced during 2013 (January-June 2013) was some 93,370, bringing the total number of displaced to some 574,000 people. UNHCR and other Shelter and NFI Cluster members have delivered emergency response assistance, collectively, to some 57,700 of the newly-displaced.
UNHCR as the co-lead agency of the Emergency Shelter and NFIs Cluster and Lead agency for the Protection Cluster continues to guide and coordinate the emergency response by partners working with IDPs. 470 shelters are planned in 2013, but not as yet completed for IDPs. UNHCR provided 53,107 NFIs during the reporting period. UNHCR is increasingly focusing on areas where we have an added value, and playing a catalytic role in identifying needs and community based responses ensuring the involvement of key stakeholders, notably in areas of health, education, and livelihoods, whilst UNHCR may intervene for where there is a clearly demonstrated need and vulnerability of the concerned IDP group, and also depending on availability of actors who can intervene.
Information management, collection and dissemination of reliable and detailed information and data on IDPs represent a key area where UNHCR is relied upon in Afghanistan. The Population Movement Tracking (PMT) database provides detailed information about IDPs i.e. places of origin and displacement (where IDPs currently live), cause of displacement, demography, age, sex, ethnicity, protection concerns, vulnerability, assistance receive, and the solutions found is recorded. During 2013 the software was revised in order to debug some of the issues raised during the implementation and installed in all of our sub-offices. One day training was conducted for all PMT focal points from the field. Based on the lessons learnt currently the questionnaire is being revised. In June 2013, a FICSS team conducted a successful mission, including field visits, reviewing all aspects of information management in Afghanistan operation. A debrief of initial findings in particular highlighted the need for a senior Information Management Officer in order to bridge the current gap between data and analysis, and allow for a more pragmatic use of the current data.
Sustainable solutions remain a serious challenge for IDPs. UNHCR supported the Afghan Government to establish a National IDP policy which envisages the development of national and provincial level action plans. The final draft of the Policy was completed and was endorsed in national consultations held in May 2013 and has been submitted to the Cabinet of Ministers for adoption. Meanwhile, greater efforts are required to address interim needs of the IDPs since they generally have little in terms of resources, have precarious shelter arrangements and a plethora of protection needs.

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Unmet Needs (O)
ElementSection.text: • A vast majority of IDPs still continue to rely on their hosting communities for assistance. While UNHCR has increased its assistance to IDPs in 2012, a large number of IDPs are in situations of protracted displacement with limited prospect of return, hence the need for longer term programs to address livelihood needs in displacement. However, the Government of Afghanistan maintains that return is the only viable solution to displacement. The national IDP policy is expected to broaden the scope of durable solutions including through national consultations, not withstanding challenges so far in its adoption, and eventual implementation process, in view of lack of government ownership in this process. • The most significant assumption regarding the future direction of internal displacement in Afghanistan is the likely growth in conflict-induced IDPs in the context of the volatility of the security situation leading up to 2014 and beyond. In view of this growing internal displacement, requirements related to emergency assistance will probably persist. The most pressing constraint of unreliable and insecure access to the conflict induced IDPs, especially in the southern and south-eastern parts of the country is expected to continue. UNHCR continues to lead the regional IDP Task Force in collaboration with other stakeholders. • Data and information management is a key priority for the Afghan operation as UNHCR is relied upon to provide credible data on both returnee and IDP populations. For example, the Population Movement Tracking system is an important tool which provides real-time information on conflict-induced population movements, root causes for movements, immediate humanitarian assistance and the approach for solutions, where possible. In June 2013, a FICSS team conducted a mission to help UNHCR Afghanistan to develop an information management strategy for the Afghanistan operation. A debrief of initial findings highlighted in particular the need for a senior Information Management Officer in order to bridge the current gap between data and analysis, and allow for a more pragmatic use of the current data. • While the Government of Afghanistan has taken important steps to improve the situation of women in the country, including the incorporation of international standards for the protection of women’s rights into national legislation, women continue to face serious obstacles in accessing basic rights, including the right to education, work, employment, and health. While through its projects, UNHCR strives to address gender issues including SGBV, there are very limited funds to pursue any significant project given the tight earmarking to other sectors.

ElementSection.sectionName: Assessment - Current Situation and Achievements to Date
ElementSection.text:
The finalisation and wide dissemination of the IDP Strategy for Afghanistan in January 2010 paved the way for a clear approach on IDP protection through the year among all regions in Afghanistan. This facilitated improved IDP identification, assessment of needs and assistance response through the year in collaboration with key partners including DoRRs and NGOs. In 2012, the Government of Afghanistan has expressed commitment to prepare a National IDP Strategy.
UNHCR’s main focus on internal displacement was on recent conflict induced displaced and the remnant protracted IDP caseloads. Responses and co-ordination to natural disasters remained within the ambit of IOM and OCHA. This was further concretised with an understanding with these two agencies however UNHCR as Protection Cluster co-ordinator continues to maintain its lead in protection co-ordination of populations affected by natural disasters. UNHCR in this instance developed a widely disseminated Protection Guidance and Checklist for persons affected by natural disasters.
UNHCR facilitated return of protracted IDPs in the course of the last years (some 11,000 in 2011) and largely all who really wanted to go back to their original homes have been assisted with transportation and reintegration projects.
The analysis of the displacement patters in 2009-2012 foresees an increase in conflict-induced displacement. Further progress is needed on IDP information, data management, IDP monitoring and coordination with other actors.

UNHCR is closely coordinating its strategies and activities with regard to with the line ministry – MoRR, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other government departments. It will continue to build to the extent possible the capacity of MoRR which is yet to become adequate to the requirements of a comprehensive task to manage the populations of concern. UNHCR intends to provide support for improving MoRR’s management capacity concentrated focused on the following key areas: policy development, institutional strengthening, emergency response, playing its coordination role with other ministries.
The leadership of UNHCR in the Protection Cluster and the National IDP Task Force, as well as the Emergency Shelter and NFIs cluster gained momentum in 2011 and will be upheld to better coordinate the assessment of the needs of IDPs and provide adequate responses, as described in other parts of the COP.
As part of the UN Country Team, UNHCR will continue to play its part in urging greater coordination and technical and financial coherence with existing policies, programmes, and implementing arrangements. New approaches will be explored and implemented in terms of focusing a concerted action of the UN agencies with regard to reintegration and returnees on the basis of joint and coordinated assessment, planning and assistance, including UN programmes in pilot provinces.
UNHCR has a range of some 75 implementing partners, essentially government departments like MoRR/DoRRs and national and international NGOs, who are traditional partners working in the areas of repatriation, shelter, income generation, water, remote monitoring, legal information and assistance, delivery of NFIs, etc. The existing arrangements proved to be efficient in the past and will continue to be used in 2013. New partnerships primarily with UN agencies will be further developed in relation to joint programme and comprehensive reintegration activities on selected sites, communities and provinces.

ElementSection.sectionName: PPG Strategy - Protection and solution strategy (comprehensive)
ElementSection.text:
In 2002, an estimated 1.2 million Afghans were internally displaced. The majority of them returned spontaneously. In 2008, UNHCR profiled the remaining IDP population. According to data from end 2011, there are approximately 450,000 IDPs in Afghanistan, and this indicates an increase of over 185,000 conflict induced IDPs from end 2010. The majority of identified IDPs constitute conflict induced displaced in recent years.
UNHCR is the designated cluster lead for Protection and Emergency Shelter and NFIs clusters in Afghanistan. UNHCR also co-leads the National IDP Task Force and the Housing Land and Property Task Force in Afghanistan.
UNHCR has led the development of a national IDP strategy, which addresses the protracted IDP caseload and has created mechanisms for responding to new displacements. UNHCR has also developed an internal IDP Strategy to standardize and harmonize its work for the internally displaced in Afghanistan and this has been implemented through 2010 and 2011.
Discrimination against IDPs exists, but it is generally due to their ethnicity or place of origin in Afghanistan, not their status as IDPs. For example, Pashtun IDPs in the West and North are, in some instances, viewed with suspicion by Tajik and Uzbek residents, who may associate them with elements of the insurgency.
Concerns remain about full and consistent implementation by ISAF of the Tactical Directives and procedures on the ground and the persistent lack of transparency on investigations and accountability for civilian casualties which have increased radically and was at its highest since casualty records began in 2007. Continuous review, analysis and evaluation of Tactical Directives and their implementation would further strengthen civilian protection by PGF.
The number of people in this PPG is 697,547

As explained at the Operation Plan level, UNHCR Afghanistan prioritized within the Operating level the activities that address the most pressing need of this PPG, i.e. relief assistance in displacement essentially in the form of NFIs, as well as a range of protection interventions, including policy development, coordination, data collection that do not entail ops budget allocations.
The logistical support to the operation, including all warehouses in the regions and transportation capacity will continue to operate with a possibility to expand the operation should more funds are made available in order to meet the needs placed above the Operating Level.
It is assumed that ongoing and potential military activities will likely prompt the necessity for a larger scale of relief assistance. In practical terms, it means adequate emergency preparedness resulting in maintenance of sizable stockpiles of NFI (for some 5,000 families) in order to be able to quickly respond to the most pressing needs of IDPs in rapidly emerging displacement circumstances. In addition, part of relief assistance will be provided to natural disaster induced persons as part of an interagency response. Logistics capacity will be maintained for the purposes of stockpiling and delivering relief assistance.
The Objective “Quality of registration and profiling improved or maintained in relation to the GSP indicator “% of IDPs for which sex and age disaggregated data is available” and the Objective “Emergency management strengthened” in relation to the GSP indicators “average # of days from onset to first delivery of protection and relief” have been prioritized.
- Assistance to facilitate IDP solutions, including return and local integration such as shelter, community-based activities, livelihood are budgeted above operating level for up to 50,000 families.

It is hoped that the Government will take more prominent responsibility in Kabul and in the provinces to manage internal displacement on the basis of UNHCR advice and documentation developed and tailored to Afghanistan specifics, and will play more efficient coordinating role. Coordination support role of UNHCR with all actors concerned in the framework of the Protection Cluster and the National IDP Task Force will continue. OCHA and IOM together with the Government will lead responses with regard to displacement caused by natural disasters while UNHCR will discharge its protection lead responsibilities.
It is assumed that security constraints will permit to reach as many IDPs in need as possible, including though available remote management mechanisms and partners.
UNHCR plans to have sufficient amount of NFIs to meaningfully assist the conflict induced IDPs, including those requiring winterization support. In the case of mass displacement beyond available capacity will have to be addressed through the activation of emergency mechanisms.

Coordination with a wide range of Government partners and other actors, including donors, will continue as it was the case in the previous years predominantly through UNCT, Protection cluster, National IDP Task Force and bilateral contacts.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: Asylum seekers and refugees have very little, if any, means to cover their health needs. They are not officially allowed to have gainful employment in Afghanistan which makes them fully dependent on UNHCR assistance.

Asylum seekers and refugees usually have access to the local health system but are not in a position to afford the cost. All health services need to be paid for and UNHCR will reimburse the persons of concern for their medical expenses, both medical visits and procurement of medicines. PoC would not have access to health if UNHCR did not cover the cost.
The funds above the operating level are meant for new arrivals.
100 eligible refugees and asylum seekers will receive support to cover the cost of medical assistance and medicines.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: As there is no national asylum law in Afghanistan and no government mechanisms exist to respond to the needs of the asylum seekers and refugees, UNHCR has to assume the role of provider of basic assistance to some 7,000 asylum seekers, refugees and persons in a refugee like situation.

Assistance to refugees and asylum-seekers will be provided on a case by case basis (some 100 individuals), to both individuals and family units and on the basis of needs assessment conducted by UNHCR Protection staff. All eligible asylum seekers and refugee will receive financial support. Rental cost and other living allowance will be covered under this objective.
The budget above operating level is meant for a projected 25 new asylum seekers arriving during the course of 2013.
100 eligible refugees and asylum seekers will receive financial support to meet their basic needs.

ElementSection.sectionName: Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment - Problem / Risk / Gap Assessment
ElementSection.text: There is no national asylum law in place, and the Government of Afghanistan does not implement RSD for asylum seekers. Therefore, UNHCR will have to determine refugee status in respect of 30 asylum seekers and eventually look at group determination modalities for over 6,000 persons in a refugee like situation should access to them be available, and provide assistance to both eligible asylum seekers and refugees. Though processing timelines are clear RSD for certain cases takes longer than required. In addition UNHCR Afghanistan will continue supporting the Government in finalizing the Law on Asylum and thereafter create structures for its implementation.

The Government of Afghanistan has established no legislation and mechanisms to deal with asylum seekers and refugees. This leaves to UNHCR to continue conducting Refugee Status Determination (RSD) for asylum-seekers. The timeframe for processing RSD in Afghanistan will be expedited. The Protection Section at the Representation in Kabul will provide guidance and oversight to the RSD processing by Sub-Offices, intervening in cases submitting an appeal against a first instance RSD rejection.
In addition, UNHCR will support the Government in finalizing the Law on Asylum and thereafter setting up of structures for implementation of the Law. As this activity depends on the willingness and capability of the Government to take over RSD, it is likely that funds for the activation of an RSD unit within MoRR will not materialize before the end of 2013. This is the reason why funds are above operating level.

Indicator.name: Extent status determination procedure meets minimum procedural standards advocated by UNHCR

ProblemObjective.problemName: Law or policy is inadequate for protection and solutions
ProblemObjective.objectiveName: Law and policy developed or strengthened

Output.name: UNHCR commentary on legal acts and drafts provided

ElementSection.text: A national refugee law shall be established, within which UNHCR shall assist in a legal advisory role.

ElementSection.sectionName: Output Operating Level - Output Operating Level

Indicator.name: # of instances of UNHCR commentary on legal acts and drafts provided

ElementSection.text:
The Government of Afghanistan has established no legislation and mechanisms to deal with asylum seekers and refugees. This leaves to UNHCR to continue conducting Refugee Status Determination (RSD) for asylum-seekers. The timeframe for processing RSD in Afghanistan will be expedited. The Protection Section at the Representation in Kabul will provide guidance and oversight to the RSD processing by Sub-Offices, intervening in cases submitting an appeal against a first instance RSD rejection.
In addition UNHCR will support the Government in finalizing the Law on Asylum and thereafter setting up of structures for implementation of the Law.
Provision will be made for legal representation of asylum seekers and refugees in courts of law if there is a need.

Due to absence of applicable refugee law, UNHCR is continuing the assessment of asylum claims under its global mandate. The sub-offices of Kabul and Hirat are reviewing the cases in the first instance, and Protection section at RA is dealing with appeal applications, supervising the process in the SOs and resettlement submissions.
National Refugee Law has been drafted by a joint commission consisted of MoRR and UNHCR staff members from protection unit by the end of 2012. In early 2013 the draft law was submitted for expert review and comments to DIP in Geneva. UNHCR Afghanistan has received comments from DIP recently and is going to submit the UNHCR finalized version to MoRR. After inclusion of comments from MoRR it will be submitted to MoJ to start the official processes of adoption of the law through MoJ, council of the ministers and parliament.

Indicator.name: Extent law and policy consistent with international standards

ElementSection.text:
As of June 2013 UNHCR recognized 79 individuals as refugees. 77 people are currently seeking asylum in Afghanistan. In total 227 individuals (175 cases) received information on status determination procedures and 97 individuals (27 cases) received food and non-food items as assistance.
Nearly 17,000 people from Kurram Agency and other border regions of Pakistan are “in a refugee like situation in Paktya, Paktika, Kunar and Nangarhar provinces of Afghanistan. UNHCR Afghanistan, through its relevant partners, is monitoring their living conditions and in some occasions has provided some assistance. MoRR has prepared a national refugee law in close consultation with UNHCR Afghanistan. It is expected that following further discussions with the authorities and advocacy with Parliamentary committees, the final text will be adopted in the course of 2014. UNHCR Afghanistan has not submitted any case for resettlement during the reporting period. However two resettlement cases are in progress and hopefully they will depart to Canada before the end of the year. Another case will be submitted to Canada soon.
UNHCR Afghanistan is in the process of drafting a National SGBV strategy. Discussions with several stakeholders have been conducted in March which formed the basis of a first draft of the strategy. UNHCR is implementing SGBV projects all over Afghanistan such as 1) GBV awareness raising training for elders and other community members (men and women) to improve prevention and strengthen the response mechanism, 2) income generation support to women, 3) awareness raising on Child protection related issues, 4) GBV awareness training to the Shuras and communities in order to strengthen their capacities to understand, identify and take preventive practical steps to reduce GBV and other harmful practices , 5) training on women rights and 6) coexistence, GVB and AGDM training. In the near future, sanitary kits (dark cotton, soap and women underwear) will be part of UNHCR’s NFI package and will be distributed to persons of concerns. In addition to being an active member of the GBV Steering Committee, which is a coordination mechanism for GBV reduction activities, UNHCR has been actively participating in other GBV coordination Mechanisms such as Gender Working Group (GWG) and Elimination of violence Against Women Special Fund (EVAW SF). The GWG is a UNCT working group chaired by UN Women and it is the UN Agencies coordination mechanism related to gender issues. UHNCR has been providing inputs and comments to different documents that were presented to UNCT by the GWG. UNHCR is an active member of the Technical Reviewing Committee of the Elimination of Violence Against Women Special Fund, and has been involved in reviewing proposals that the Fund received. This fund ensures a streamlined and predictable framework for funding projects and activities by focusing on prevention, protection mechanisms and access to justice. The fund strives to co-ordinate all activities related to SGBV and supports the Afghan Ministry of Women’s Affairs (MOWA) and its provincial departments (DOWAs).

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Unmet Needs (O)
ElementSection.text: • Whilst the Government of Afghanistan respects the principle of non refoulement, asylum seekers and refugees face protection concerns related to the volatile security situation and difficulties in accessing basic services. Efforts are undertaken by UNHCR to advocate for the inclusion of this group into national services (education, health services and vocational training) pending the finalization and implementation of the national law on asylum and refugees. In this regard, a MOU with the Ministry of Public Health and MORR is in the process of finalization.

ElementSection.sectionName: Assessment - Current Situation and Achievements to Date
ElementSection.text: Afghanistan is party to the 1951 Convention and its 1967 Protocol. However, in the absence of relevant national legislation and corresponding mechanisms, UNHCR continues to ensure registration, RSD and material assistance to this PPG

UNHCR is closely coordinating its strategies and activities with regard to with the line ministry – MoRR, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other government departments. It will continue to build to the extent possible the capacity of MoRR which is yet to become adequate to the requirements of a comprehensive task to manage the populations of concern. UNHCR intends to provide support for improving MoRR’s management capacity concentrated focused on the following key areas: policy development, institutional strengthening, emergency response, playing its coordination role with other ministries.
The leadership of UNHCR in the Protection Cluster and the National IDP Task Force, as well as the Emergency Shelter and NFIs cluster gained momentum in 2011 and will be upheld to better coordinate the assessment of the needs of IDPs and provide adequate responses, as described in other parts of the COP.
As part of the UN Country Team, UNHCR will continue to play its part in urging greater coordination and technical and financial coherence with existing policies, programmes, and implementing arrangements. New approaches will be explored and implemented in terms of focusing a concerted action of the UN agencies with regard to reintegration and returnees on the basis of joint and coordinated assessment, planning and assistance, including UN programmes in pilot provinces.
UNHCR has a range of some 75 implementing partners, essentially government departments like MoRR/DoRRs and national and international NGOs, who are traditional partners working in the areas of repatriation, shelter, income generation, water, remote monitoring, legal information and assistance, delivery of NFIs, etc. The existing arrangements proved to be efficient in the past and will continue to be used in 2013. New partnerships primarily with UN agencies will be further developed in relation to joint programme and comprehensive reintegration activities on selected sites, communities and provinces.

ElementSection.sectionName: PPG Strategy - Protection and solution strategy (comprehensive)
ElementSection.text:
As of the end of 2011, UNHCR registered 66 refugees (mandate recognition), 53 asylum-seekers. This group is composed of urban individuals and families, and is concentrated in the cities of Kabul and Heart.
Number in this PPG is 7,577

In view of small numbers of PoC under this PPG, all eligible refugees and the most vulnerable asylum seekers will receive material support. Individuals in the refugee like situation will receive relief assistance as much as access to them will be possible either directly or through implementing and/or operational partners.
- Support for the implementation of passed refugee legislation, and assistance to the Government of Afghanistan to put in place RSD mechanisms;

It is expected that the number of PoC under this PPG will remain small. It does not seem realistic that the Government will be able to take over from UNHCR RSD and assistance. Therefore the office will continue to fulfill it role as in the previous years.
UNHCR plans, however, to start assisting the relevant Government departments in drafting national refugee legislation and undergo on-the-job training in refugee matters.

The Office will explore potential partnership with selected NGOs in a position to support refugees and asylum-seekers becoming more self-reliant. Foreseen partnerships with NGOs in 2012 will focus on promoting local integration for individually recognized refugees.
In relation to the Pakistani populations in a refugee like situation UNHCR will continue to engage with NGOs and government agencies enjoying access to these populations.

A Trilateral meeting between the Governments of Pakistan and Afghanistan, and UNHCR took place on 28 June 2013 where the GoP provided information about its proposed national policy on Afghan refugees which includes the recommendation for the extension of the Proof of Registration cards until 31 December 2015, subject to the approval of its cabinet. Five Encashment Centers continue to provide an average individual 150 USD grant, provide health, legal and social counselling as well as information on mine and ordnance risks.
In line with the Solutions Strategy, UNHCR continued to pursue during 2013 a reintegration strategy aiming at facilitating the transition from humanitarian to development assistance. In this context, UNHCR has been working primarily with UNDP during 2013, in the framework of the Letter of Intent to which ILO and the Resident Coordinator are also parties, signed in February 2013. The joint Voluntary Repatriation and Reintegration Project will be revised in this respect to include ILO and potentially other development partners. UNHCR is also actively engaged in the CCA/UNDAF process for 2014-2019 to ensure refugee returnees and internally displaced are considered in development priorities identified by the UNCT. UNHCR has also been advocating with the Government to ensure returnee reintegration receives further political support and visibility. An inter-ministerial committee is to be set up to this effect under the chairmanship of the 2nd Vice President of Afghanistan.
During the reporting period, UNHCR continued to focus its reintegration activities in 16 high return areas previously identified, in the context of the Solutions Strategy for Afghan Refugees. In the Eastern region, UNHCR undertook needs assessment in newly identified areas in order to accommodate new return trends and settlement locations. Participatory needs assessments will be conducted in the areas of high return particularly those not covered under the pilot reintegration sites. This approach will be mainstreamed throughout the country for needs assessments for 2014 projects.
1,343 shelters are planned for refugee returnees in 2013 construction of which have started. Access to adequate shelter is a key determinant of initial reintegration for the returnees and hence a cornerstone of UNHCR’s reintegration strategy in Afghanistan. Infrastructure interventions implemented through short term Cash For Work (CFW) subsistence projects are also on-going. Infrastructure projects provide sustainability to the returnee and surrounding communities including access to services and livelihoods opportunities. During 2013, UNHCR is mapping development partners in respective regions and their respective activities with a view to gradually phasing out development-type interventions whilst UNHCR may continue some of these activities in areas where there is an obvious immediate gap. Those objectives that have been prioritized relate to shelter assistance, provision of non-food items, protection and assistance to persons with specific needs. For health, WASH, livelihoods and education objectives, referral mechanisms are prioritized.
UNHCR continued to further enhance emergency response to new conflict-induced displacement, including through the provision of appropriate and sufficient non-food items and through its broader inter-agency coordination role on protection and emergency shelter/NFIs. When it comes to IDP solutions UNHCR focuses on areas where we have an added value, and playing a catalytic role in identifying needs and community based responses ensuring the involvement of key stakeholders in sectors such as education and health. The UNHCR-supported national IDP policy was endorsed in national consultations held in May 2013. The Policy has been submitted to the Cabinet of Ministers for adoption. Meanwhile, greater efforts are required to address interim needs of the IDPs.

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Unmet Needs
ElementSection.text: • Challenges to a sustainable reintegration process remain vast and include insecurity and conflict, shortage of land, housing/shelter and livelihood opportunities. UNHCR alone will never be able to attain sustainable reintegration of the large number of returnees (5.7 million since 2002) in view of the lack of absorption capacity in the country. This is compounded by limited government capacity to provide infrastructure and deliver basic services, coupled with a significant “urbanization” of returnees, protection concerns (including gender inequalities), as well as frequent natural disasters. While the Solutions Strategy for Afghan Returnees has captured a portion of the needs to catalyse sustainable reintegration, the mobilization of development actors continues to remain a slow and challenging process. • The main issues affecting reintegration of returnees are lack of shelters, job opportunities, and access to basic facilities including health and education. 1,343 shelters are planned for refugee returnees in 2013 under the OL which is far below the comprehensive target of 6,065. UNHCR is currently reviewing the recommendation of the shelter evaluation carried out in 2012 (Maastricht University/Samuel Hall) in order to strengthen and improve, where feasible, specific areas of implementation in the current year (2013). Through the establishment of a Shelter Working Group in Kabul and the mission of the shelter specialist from UNHCR’s HQs in Geneva in May 2013, UNHCR is currently revising present guidelines in consultation with all relevant stakeholders (government and all shelter cluster members). However, as recommended by the Shelter specialist, a comprehensive review of the guidelines and implementation modalities may require the services of a dedicated consultant. • While the Government of Afghanistan has taken important steps to improve the situation of women in the country, including the incorporation of international standards for the protection of women’s rights into national legislation, women continue to face serious obstacles in accessing basic rights, including the right to education, work, employment, and health. While through its projects, UNHCR strives to address gender issues including SGBV, there are very limited funds to pursue any significant project given the tight earmarking to other sectors. • Data and information management is a key priority for the Afghan operation as UNHCR is relied upon to provide credible data on both returnee and IDP populations. For example, the Population Movement Tracking system is an important tool which provides real-time information on conflict-induced population movements, root causes for movements, immediate humanitarian assistance and the approach for solutions, where possible. In June 2013, the HQ FICSS team conducted a mission to help UNHCR Afghanistan to develop an information management strategy. A debrief of initial findings highlighted in particular the need for a senior Information Management Officer in order to bridge the current gap between data and analysis, and allow for a more pragmatic use of the current data.

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Management Plan
ElementSection.text:
UNHCR Afghanistan Office and staffing structure has not undergone major changes during the reporting period. UNHCR Afghanistan continues to face serious challenges to fill international professional posts in a timely manner, usually related to the lack of qualified candidates, necessitating re-advertisement. To cover the key positions, the Office utilizes short-term assignment of SIBAs or recruiting external candidates under Temporary Appointments charged to the existing vacant positions. The Staffing gap is expected to last until the end of the year when most of the vacant positions will hopefully be filled. With reference to IOM/105-FOM/106/2012 - Enhancing the Project Control Function, Representation Afghanistan proposed upgrading of the current P2 Associate Project Control Officer position to P4 Senior Project Control Officer effective July 2013. The position will be filled by a TA from SIBA for six months. Security situation in Afghanistan has deteriorated requiring some premises to move from the current guesthouse accommodation in Kabul and Herat. This requirement is based on the recommendations of the FSS team locally and from HQ. The cost of dismantling all the installations including the prefabricated offices and restoring premises to its original condition, cost of double rent for 4-6 months while renovating the new premises and making them MOSS compliant is estimated at USD 360,000.00 for Kabul and SO Herat including the expected double rent for 4-6 months for the Kabul accommodation and office premises. The major challenge we are facing is the identification of a new, MOSS compliant, in a secure location and with reasonable cost guesthouse and office premises. This activity was planned and the funds were available in the ABOD. In 2012 UNHCR Afghanistan ABOD target was increased for implementation of various security recommendations for MOSS upgrades including the blast mitigation measures. No security enhancements are expected in 2013 apart from making the new premises MOSS compliant. However, we do not have the figure for this as no premises have been identified as yet. The disruption of the regular work schedule has continued during this year and movement restrictions imposed. As the security will further deteriorate, Business Continuity Plan has proposed for the purchase of laptops for staff to work from home, contact with HQs has been made to introduce the electronic filing system (e-SAFE) to access documents from everywhere in case of relocation or evacuation, payments effected through Treasury and maintaining low cash ceiling in the bank are among the actions taken. This would ensure smooth continuity under worsening security situation. The costs related to the above activities were factored in the 2013 budget and no additional increase is required in the ABOD for this particular activity. Guards and cleaning services were outsourced to a company effective January 2013. USD 650,000 was budgeted for 2013. Due to the complication experienced it was decided to increase the salaries from the planned USD 250 to USD 850 and one month Eid Allowance. The cost increased to USD 2,317,000. The additional cost has affected our planned activities. Overall expenditure as of 30/06/2013 was 74.2% excluding requisitions representing about 7.2%, leaving us with the balance of 18%. All the planned activities including: - relocation of guest houses and office + ICT/Telecom installations USD 600,000 - double rent while renovating the new premises (4 months) USD 210,000 - restoration of premises to its original condition USD 150,000 - business continuity plan activities USD 60,000 - spare parts for armored vehicles USD 120,000 - Upgrade ICT to CISCO standards and move to Outlook USD 560,000 - day to day running costs approx. USD 300,000 per month X 6mnts USD 1,800,000
We therefore need an additional USD 1.2 million to cover for the above essential needs.

ElementSection.sectionName: Protection and Operations Strategy - Partnership; coordination and contributions
Protection and Operations Strategy - Code of Conduct Report
Protection and Operations Strategy - Staff Development Report
Protection and Operations Strategy - Resource Mobilization
Refugees - Overview of the Protection Situation
ElementSection.text:
As of the end of 2011, UNHCR registered 66 refugees (mandate recognition), 51 asylum-seekers. This group is composed of urban individuals and families, and is concentrated in the cities of Kabul and Herat. In addition, an estimated population of 2,934 individual Pakistani nationals remains living in a refugee like situation along the Afghan side of the border with Pakistan.
Serious security constraints continue to hinder direct UNHCR access to the Pakistani nationals living in a refugee like situation along the border. Material assistance and attention to vulnerable cases are provided in effect by partners on the ground and the government has until now respected its commitment to the principle of non-refoulement in regard to this particular group of refugees.

Afghanistan ratified the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol on 30 August 2005. Both instruments were translated into Dari and Pashto (the official languages of Afghanistan) and published in the Official Gazette of the Ministry of Justice on 22 October 2006, thereby forming part of the national legal framework. However, following the pledge held by the Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation (MoRR), at the Ministerial meeting of 7-8 December 2011, the Government of Afghanistan placed the preparation and draft of a national Refugee Law high on its political agenda and set it as a priority for the Government. In this regard, a joint working group composed by MoRR and UNHCR staff, was established during the summer of 2011 with the main responsibility of drafting a national legislation in conformity with international norms and best practices.
UNHCR is not aware of the Government of Afghanistan limiting access to asylum or violating the principle of non-refoulement. With the increasing number of Pakistani nationals crossing the border due to sectarian violence, conflict and instability, UNHCR will continue monitor the government’s commitment to non-refoulement. Security constraints to access border regions, especially along the Pakistani border, may hinder UNHCR efforts on this front.

At the current time, and while the joint working group composed by MoRR and UNHCR staff, works on drafting a national legislation in conformity with international norms and best practices, and until it’s final adoption UNHCR will continue to carry out mandate RSD and resettlement in Afghanistan.
Upon registration, UNHCR provides asylum seekers with letters which confirm their status, indicate that their asylum petitions are under review, and note that they should not be detained or deported while a final decision is pending. Copies of these letters are systematically shared with the government and are normally respected by authorities.
Although most asylum seekers have not been detained in recent years, there is no clear policy on the side of the government regarding detention or alternatives to detention.
Where necessary, UNHCR assumes responsibility for the care and maintenance of asylum seekers and refugees.

As a general matter, those asylum seekers and refugees of whom UNHCR is aware face security and protection concerns similar to those described for the Returnee and IDP populations. UNHCR has used and will continue to use resettlement as a protection tool to intervene in situations of refugees facing physical protection needs and refugee women being confronted with risks and threats to their physical integrity, especially in relation to different forms of domestic and SGBV.

Although the population of asylum seekers and refugees is relatively small in Afghanistan, especially if compared to the Office’s responsibilities vis-à-vis returnees and IDPs, UNHCR actively consults such persons of concern and assesses their needs through field visits, home assessments and interviews with stakeholders, taking into account AGDM principles.
Achieving self-reliance with the ultimate goal to integrate in the fragile Afghan economy is particularly challenging for asylum seekers and refugees who recently arrived, do not speak local languages, lack local connections, or do not have the support of co-nationals.
Accordingly, UNHCR works closely with such persons of concern to facilitate, where possible, their adaptation to the local environment, also resorting to resettlement for individual cases facing particularly serious protection needs.
As UNHCR continues to be confronted with the lack of access to the populations of Pakistanis living in a refugee like situation along border areas, meetings have been organized with community leaders. In such instances, and whenever possible and not posing threats to them, UNHCR tries to facilitate the direct access of these leaders to our offices.

Unfortunately, the Government of Afghanistan does not have the capacity to assist asylum seekers and refugees, who continue to benefit from UNHCR material assistance. If necessary, basic needs such as accommodation, medicines, medical treatment and food are duly covered. UNHCR may also use its network of agencies attending to the needs of vulnerable individuals. Assistance may also be provided to facilitate counseling, medical care, language training and vocational training.
In principle, the government recognizes the right to work for asylum seekers and refugees, although there is no clear policy or domestic legislation in this regard.
In practice, asylum seekers and refugees have enjoyed access to primary, secondary and higher education institutions, in addition to the limited health care and other social services in the country. Discussions relating to the full access of asylum seekers and refugees to free public health services have started in 2012 with the Ministry of Public Health and are ongoing.
The most urgent material needs, such as food and non-food items, among the Pakistani nationals along the border regions, continue to be covered by UNHCR partners on the ground enjoying access to these populations.

Given the fragile economy and complex security situation in Afghanistan, local integration is challenging, although several cases have successfully done so. UNHCR continues to explore partnerships with NGOs in a position to support refugees and asylum-seekers becoming self-reliant, with the ultimate goal to facilitate their integration.
As noted, legal and physical protection concerns have compelled resettlement promotion in a small number of cases. Resettlement will continue to be strategically used as a protection tool and UNHCR envisages the need of resettlement for some 10 individual refugees throughout 2012 and 2013.
Voluntary repatriation has rarely been indicated as a solution by the individual refugees, but may be an option for some cases in the future.
While trying to reinforce its protection monitoring role over the situation of the Pakistanis in a refuge like situation along remote border regions, the current situation indicates that voluntary repatriation remains the most preferred solution by these populations. Nevertheless, this cannot be assumed under the present circumstances in their areas of origin. UNHCR will continue to explore alternative ways to better access and understand these populations’ protection needs while considering eventual solutions.

ElementSection.sectionName: Returnees - Overview of the Protection Situation
ElementSection.text:
The Office foresees the voluntary return of 172,000 refugees from neighboring countries, the overall majority - 150,000- from Pakistan, while 20,000 from Iran. Other 2,000 returnees are expected from other countries, mainly the Russian Federation and India, in addition to returnees from different Central Asian countries.
The remaining refugee population in Iran and, especially, Pakistan, represent families that have been in exile for decades and longer terms. This means that these families, upon eventual return, are likely to face more obstacles than other returnee families that have lived abroad for less time.
Issues such as access to house, land and property rights, including restitution claims and the special needs among landless returnees, and the ability to become self-reliant in a short or medium term will present more serious obstacles if compared to returnee families that have spent less years as refugees abroad. Families returning after decades in exile are likely to have many more family members, including the vulnerable elderly, adolescents that may have never been to their own country – therefore presenting adaptability challenges - and school-age children, including girls, who may face obstacles trying to access education in Afghanistan.
Returnees from a long-term in exile are therefore expected to look for re-integration alternatives in Afghanistan’s urban centers rather than opting to re-establish in their rural villages of origin.
Concerns remain over the current absorption capacity of the country, which remains severally strained. Through monitoring and the systematic identification of vulnerable returnee families in the Encashment Centers, the office intends to intervene and support cases facing special protection needs, with particular emphasis on families with children, female headed families and elderly returnees.
The landless status of many returnees, land and property rights disputes, the limited success of the Government-led Land Allocation Scheme (LAS), the increasingly volatile security situation, the deterioration of the ongoing armed conflict and overall poverty prevailing in Afghanistan continue to prevent returnees from reintegrating in their places of origin.
Profiling exercises being implemented by UNHCR on areas of return will continue informing the Office and facilitating a better understanding of the current situation being faced by returnees in an IDP like situation, with particular emphasis to their protection needs.

The voluntary return process is governed by Tripartite Agreements with neighboring countries (Iran and Pakistan) and non-neighboring countries (Australia, Denmark, France, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK).
The Article 39 of the Afghan Constitution (2004) recognizes the right to return. The Decree 297 on Dignified Return of Refugees (2001) establishes the right to recover property, bans discrimination, and constitutes a legal basis for UNHCR monitoring. The Presidential Decree 104 on “Land Distribution for Settlement of Eligible Returnees and IDPs” (December 2005) continues to serve as the main legal framework intended to facilitate landless returnees’ access to land and therefore promote their reintegration. Notwithstanding such norms, some returnees face difficulties recovering property and re-integrating. Complex ethnic, political and/or socio-economic factors are often at play.
In some instances, returnee girls and women face discrimination or abuse because, after living abroad, they have adopted more progressive social mores. In addition, over thirty years of war and internal disturbances have taken a heavy toll on Afghanistan’s environment. Farmland and grassland degradation, landmines, and deforestation pose challenges for sustainable returns and reduce Afghanistan’s already limited absorption capacity.

As a result of complex security, political and socio-economic factors, the overwhelming majority of Afghan refugees in Iran and Pakistan are not currently opting for voluntary repatriation. However it is expected that there will be higher returns from Iran and particularly Pakistan in view of the official announcement by the Pakistani authorities of the non-renewal of all POR card of Afghan refugees at the end of 2012. The majority of refugees who are thus expected to voluntarily repatriate will originate from Pakistan (150,000). Returnees proceed to the Encashment Centers (ECs), where they receive a reintegration and transportation grant, other services and information.
The ECs are primarily staffed with UNHCR and MoRR personnel. Staff from the NRC-administered Information Counseling and Legal Assistance (ICLA) programme are present at ECs to provide legal aid advice to returnees. A variety of other implementing partners and agencies provide emergency medical care, polio and measles vaccinations, and mine-risk education. All ECs have basic overnight transit facilities.
At the border crossing points, MoRR staff monitors deported persons and persons returning spontaneously. The purpose of border monitoring is to identify the general trends of cross-border movement, collect data, identify possible cases of refoulement, and identify extremely vulnerable cases, who are assisted by UNHCR and implementing partners, regardless of the status.
Given the unstable nature of the Pakistan-Afghanistan border, MoRR performs only informal border monitoring at Torkham (Afghanistan-Pakistan border after the Khyber Pass). Monitoring along the Iranian border is systematic at Milak-Zaranj and Dogharoun-Islam Qala crossing points, and supported by UNHCR staff.
Border monitoring at Kabul International airport is done systematically through IOM and MORR. UNHCR remains in close contact with MoRR with regards to cases of Afghans being returned either voluntarily or forcibly after having failed in their asylum bid, mostly in European states, particularly when specific cases require our follow-up upon return.
Individual documentation (taskera) is obtained at the local Department of Population Registration at the Ministry of the Interior in Kabul, or in the province of registration of the person’s father. The only requirement is a copy of the personal documentation of the father or a father’s relative.
In Afghanistan, there is no effective national birth registration system, and the births of many children, especially in the rural areas, are not recorded. In theory, birth registration is required to get individual documentation during the first year of age, but this is not always enforced.
Generally, a problem of individual documentation particular to returnees involves obstacles for the person to return to his or her village of origin. The Kuchi returnees (typically nomadic) from Pakistan continue to face serious obstacles when trying to obtain individual documentation.

Landlessness, property disputes, mostly over land, housing and water sources, are an important obstacle to return and reintegration for new returnees in Afghanistan. UNHCR funds and supports NRC in the running of Information and Legal Aid Centers in many parts of the country, which provide relevant legal services and conduct training for lawyers, judges and local authorities, including the community elders’ councils, often the preferred traditional justice mechanism body by most returnees.
Returnees who are not able to return to their place of origin may face exclusion and discrimination, particularly if they are an ethnic minority in the area.
Armed conflict is undermining efforts to create an environment conducive to return. In areas under the control of non-state armed groups, there is little if any state, UN or NGO presence, thereby limiting services and aid. Threats, killings and forced displacement of persons perceived as collaborating with the government or international agents are common. In urban areas, indiscriminate suicide attacks by insurgents are increasing and have killed many civilians, undermining confidence in the government’s ability to protect citizens.
The most important impact of armed conflict is the lack of access by government and humanitarian actors to some parts of the country. Following the attack on the UNAMA compound in Marzar-i-Sharif in April and the attack on the UNHCR Offices in Kandahar in October, it is now difficult to maintain that non-state armed groups continue to perceive international organizations in Afghanistan, including the UN, as impartial.
Children face a wide range of protection concerns, including child labor, smuggling and human trafficking, and early or forced marriage. UNHCR responds to the issues of child protection mainly through assistance to the Extremely Vulnerable Individuals (EVI), helping and tracing UAMs at the Iranian and Pakistani borders, and participating in the UNICEF-led Child Protection Network (CPAN).
Violence against women, in all its forms, continues to be one of the most serious, pervasive and deeply rooted protection problems in Afghanistan. Although women from all social and ethnic groups are affected, returnee girls and women who have adopted more progressive social mores abroad are particularly at risk. Social and economic independence for women are not accepted social patterns. Participation in the political process for most women remains limited. UNHCR has promoted GBV awareness training throughout the country in 2011 and will continue to do so in 2012. UNHCR has been advocating, and will continue to do so, with interested parties for the purpose of finding durable solutions the specific cases of women currently staying in women shelters for their own protection

MoRR staff, with UNHCR support, conducts monitoring at ECs. Through random interviews with returnees, information is gathered regarding the voluntary character of return, reasons for the decision to return (including pull and push factors), and conditions and respect for basic rights in the country of asylum. Observations and findings from interviews with returnees are regularly shared with UNHCR offices in host countries, discussed at tripartite commission or working group meetings, and used to make interventions to address specific problems.
Although hampered by insecurity and limited access, UNHCR uses two broad systems to consult returnees facing an IDP-like situation and assess their needs: (1) yearly needs assessments, implemented by each Sub-Office through field visits and interviews with stakeholders; (2) PAs within the AGDM framework.

Discrimination against returnees does exist, particularly in the context of access to land, but it is generally due to their ethnicity or place of origin in Afghanistan, not their status as returnees.
In general terms, food security remains a major issue in Afghanistan and it affects returnees.
Access to potable water and water for irrigation is also a problem and, in the context of land disputes, water rights are often at issue.
Providing adequate shelter to returnees is an ongoing challenge, and UNHCR continues to implement shelter projects. Landlessness, however, is often the biggest obstacle to adequate access to shelter for returnees. Decree 104 on Land Distribution for the Housing of Eligible Returnees and IDPs (2005) provides the legal framework for the Land Allocation Scheme (LAS) in Afghanistan. MoRR has played a leading role in the LAS, and been involved in the selection of beneficiaries, technical assessments and the coordination of finance and budgetary concerns. Irregularities have been detected in the selection of beneficiaries and allocation of land by MoRR staff.
The LAS suffers from inadequate criteria and transparency in the selection of beneficiaries. Because of poor planning and preparation, families have moved to sites without adequate shelter, infrastructure, social services and/or income generation activities. Some officials involved in the LAS have also discriminated against Kuchis.
UNHCR continues to advocate for the fair treatment of Kuchis in the land allocation context.
Certain categories of returnees are particularly vulnerable and require additional support to address acute protections concerns and facilitate their reintegration. UNHCR support to Extremely Vulnerable Individuals (EVIs) is one mechanism for assisting such returnees. It contemplates two lines of assistance: support via networks of service providers (state, international and civil society actors) and, in some instances, cash assistance. UNHCR works close with MoRR and its provincial authorities to implement this activity.
The extent of real reintegration of returnees particularly after 2006 is not entirely known to UNHCR, and the Office will start in 2011 and will continue to pursue in 2012 the task of establishing better statistics and knowledge in this respect in order to inform programme destined to this PPG.

Voluntary repatriation will continue to form an important component of the operation in Afghanistan, although it is likely that negative factors (insecurity, armed conflict, violence, economic pressure and the closure of refugee settlements in neighboring countries) will increasingly be significant drivers of return.
“De facto” social and economic integration in the countries of asylum, most particularly Iran and Pakistan, together with the limited absorption capacity of Afghanistan, will continue to be important factors constraining voluntary repatriation.
Reconstruction and development efforts have not advanced as quickly as hoped for and the absorption capacity in Afghanistan is increasingly limited. Concomitantly, armed conflict is intensifying and security conditions are deteriorating, thereby reducing humanitarian access, which impedes assistance and development efforts and contributes to an environment that, in some instances, may not be conducive to returns, particularly in the south, southeast and east of the country.
It is likely that core protection concerns will pose obstacles to repatriation and re-integration in conflict-affected regions of the country.

Pillar- 1 UNHCR Afghanistan will continue to facilitate voluntary repatriation to Afghanistan, including from countries that continue to host Afghan refugees, including from Pakistan and the Islamic Republic of Iran. Returning refugees will be provided with voluntary repatriation grants, equivalent to 150 USD per person, following processing in Voluntary Repatriation Centres in Iran and Pakistan. Five encashment centres will process returning refugees and provide the grant, as well as assess the voluntary nature of their repatriation, provide health, legal and social counseling as well as receive information about mine and ordnance risks.
Following their return to their place of origin, the most vulnerable returnees will be assessed and provided with an in-kind or cash grant. Legal counseling and support will also be provided through a network of information counseling and legal advice centres (ICLAs).
Regional meetings, including regular quadpartite meetings, will be convened to discuss voluntary repatriation and sustainable reintegration.
UNHCR seeks to ensure that the Government leads the voluntary repatriation and sustainable reintegration process.
Logistics will continue to support the operation, including maintaining five warehouses throughout Afghanistan, vehicle maintenance workshops, support to ensure transportation of shelter and other humanitarian assistance and the provision and transport of fuel.
Pillar- 3 UNHCR will continue to pursue a systematic returnee monitoring system, in places where direct access is possible as well as in other high return areas through partners. Returnee information is intended to identify the overall return environment, including their level of parity with other community members, their security situation and access to justice mechanisms as well as social and economic challenges, including access to basic services (such as health care, water and other social services), just governance and security concerns.
UNHCR will continue to pursue a transitional reintegration scheme, with a view to bridging the gap between humanitarian and development assistance. UNHCR will support that high return areas are included as priorities for National Priority Programmes and that development funds include refugee returnees in their design and implementation plans. To address any gaps, UNHCR will identify up to 15 reintegration sites to directly support reintegration assistance, targeting specifically locations with a high proportion of returnees, areas that have been under-served by development or humanitarian assistance and where direct access is possible. It is foreseen that this will be done in partnership with UNDP.
The reintegration sites targeted for assistance will be provided through a community-based support for returning refugees and other community members to improve basic services (health, water and education), protection, livelihood and shelter.
To monitor the impact of reintegration assistance, and to determine the impact of the reintegration site model, monitoring and evaluation (M&E) activities will be supported throughout the year.
Pillar- 4 It is also envisaged to further strengthen the broader coordination role within the humanitarian community built on the achievements of the previous years, including UNHCR crucial role in the Protection Cluster, National IDP Task Force, the Emergency Shelter/NFIs Cluster and drafting of a national IDP Policy.
UNHCR will continue to further enhance emergency response to new conflict-induced displacement, including through the provision of appropriate and sufficient non-food item kits.
UNHCR will also continue to support the Population Movement Tracking system, to provide real-time access and coordination as to the magnitude of conflict-induced population movements, root causes for movements, immediate humanitarian assistance and the approach for solutions, where possible.

Refugees/Asylum-seekers/People in a refugee-like situation
Assistance and protection to the most vulnerable asylum-seekers, refugees and people in a refugee-like situation are prioritized including for health assistance, individual family support and assistance to people with specific needs. In total, up to 100 people will receive this assistance, all of which falls within Pillar 1.
Returning Refugees
Prioritized assistance to returning refugees is voluntary repatriation cash grants for a total of 67,000 returning refugees. In addition, earmarked activities (from the Government of Denmark/Danida and the EC) have been prioritized within Pillar 3, and include legal assistance for up to 5,000 returning refugees, returnee monitoring, 5,000 shelters, water projects, livelihood activities for up to 20,000 returning refugees and assistance to some 1,000 most vulnerable returning refugees and their families.
IDPs
Prioritized activities include logistics and supply, to ensure that emergency response can respond to immediate needs of conflict-inducted IDPs for emergency assistance (as well as ensure that five warehouses can remain operational from the outset of the year). In addition, earmarked funds from Danida are prioritized and includes IDP monitoring, procurement of 5,000 NFI kits, assistance to some 1,000 most vulnerable IDPs and assistance to people with specific needs.
UNHCR Afghanistan has also prioritized ensuring that required support operational infrastructure is in place from the outset of the year, including office and guesthouse premises, armed security guards and other administrative costs (ABOD). Post increases requested from the outset of the year is necessary, as during 2012 it was not possible to get Budget Committee approval to create posts that had been budgeted above operating level, even once the funding was secured. Within this context, it has been decided to create international programme and administrative posts for sub-offices and in Kabul to reduce the risk of fraud and mis-use of funds, as well as to improve overall programming within the increasingly changing IDP and reintegration environment.

For voluntary repatriation and returning refugees
UNHCR will continue to work with the Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation to support capacity-building, and where possible, handover responsibilities related to voluntary repatriation, border monitoring and provision of assistance to the most vulnerable. MoRR has committed to further operationalizing its role as a coordinating ministry to respond to the challenges of returning refugees and improving return conditions, and in that regard, will continue with an Inter-Ministerial Coordination Committee (IMCC) to promote a coordinated approach for strategies and implementation of activities to pursue sustainable reintegration. The National Priority Programmes (NPPs) offer another mechanism by which MoRR will pursue a coordinated approach to ensuring that returning refugees are mainstreamed as a priority concern population within the national development framework.
UNHCR will continue its engagement with UNCT members, as well as international and national NGOs including Agency Coordinating Body for Afghan Relief (ACBAR) to promote a coordinated approach to addressing sustainable reintegration.
The regional approach to pursuing comprehensive solutions will be pursued through regular bi-annual or quarterly meetings of the quadpartite steering committee, with the three regional governments and UNHCR.
For asylum-seekers refugees
UNHCR will support MoRR to complete the drafting of refugee legislation and the legislative process to advocate for the law’s passage, promulgation and implementation.
For IDPs
As part of the UN Country Team, and under the leadership of the Humanitarian Coordinator (who serves also as the Resident Coordinator, Deputy SRSG as well as the Head of UNDP), UNHCR will play its part in urging greater coordination and technical and financial coherence with existing policies, programmes, and implementing arrangements. The Office’s role as the Protection and the Emergency Shelter and NFIs cluster lead, as well as co-chair of the National and Regional IDP task force will be upheld to contribute to respective inter-agency action in Kabul and in the regions. Cooperation with IOM as the focal designated agency for the co-ordination of natural disaster induced displacements, assistance to vulnerable deportees and migration issues, as well as OCHA, will be strengthened

Overall
It is expected that the Government of Afghanistan will take a leading role in all aspects of UNHCR’s work, including in developing strategies and legislation for people of UNHCR’s concern and will be receptive to UNHCR’s support to strengthen its capacity to improve implementation. The NPP framework will be a supportive process, and even if there are some unevenness in its implementation, implementation will progressively strengthen and benefit Afghan returnees as well as IDPs.
The UN Country Team will continue to play a supportive role to the Government process, though with a reduced interest to play a direct implementation role, and instead provide technical expertise to assist with Government implementation. Donors, likewise, will provide expertise, funding and capacity-building support to ensure Afghan ownership and leadership in all areas of governance.
Nonetheless, it is expected that humanitarian access will continue to be limited, and perhaps worsen, during 2012. Attacks may continue to target international military as well as against organizations perceived to be foreign in nature. Though UNHCR continues to make headway in seeking humanitarian access directly and through partners, operational momentum is constrained with limited freedom of movement, which hinders direct discussions with people of concern, visits to affected areas and challenges in coordinating assistance with other actors.
Afghan returnees
Voluntary repatriation will continue to be a primary durable solution promoted by neighbouring countries. Mechanisms will be put in place to ensure the voluntary nature of return and identified benchmarks and response plans prepared should forced repatriation occur. UNHCR will maintain its voluntary repatriation support through its five encashment centres. Border and returnee monitoring will be in place, and sufficient support will be provided to ensure that people are able to sustainably reintegrate in their places of origin.
UNHCR will sign an agreement with UNDP to support a transition from relief to development, to support sustainable reintegration, with the Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation supported to play a leading coordinated role. Regular dialogue will be maintained through the quadpartite discussions with neighbouring countries in UNHCR to monitor the situation of voluntary repatriation, sustainable reintegration and assistance to host communities.
IDPs
Conflict-induced internal displacement will continue, and likely increase by up to 25% during 2013. UNHCR will maintain within the framework of the humanitarian coordination mechanism emergency response capacity, especially in terms of protection and emergency shelter/NF

The Representation in Afghanistan (RA) will continue to lead the operation, with six sub-offices including in Kabul, Jalalabad, Kandahar, Herat, Mazar-i-Sharif and Gardez. There are a total of four field units, including two reporting to Herat (Islam Qala and Zaranj), two to Mazar (Maimana and Kunduz). There is one Field Office in Bamyan, reporting to SO Kabul (Bamyan). In total, UNHCR has presence in 11 locations in Afghanistan.
The overall operation will continue to be led by a Representative (D1), supported by a Deputy Representative (P5), Assistant Representative (Programme) (P5) and Assistant Representative (Administration) (P-5). To ensure harmonization and reflecting the increased importance of protection as a part of the integral strategy related to returning refugees and IDPs, the P4 Snr. Protection Officer Post will be upgraded to the P5 level entitled Assistant Representative (Protection).
An overall staffing review has been done for sub-offices, field offices and field units with a view to ensuring harmonization, reducing the risk of fraud, and ensuring sufficient capacity to lead the sustainable reintegration and IDP Strategy forward. As such, international 1 Associate Admin Officers P2 officer post will be created for Sub-Office Herat and 3 Associate Programme Officers P2 will be created for SOs Mazar, Herat and Jalalabad. For Kandahar an Admin/Programme P3, position will be created. To ensure improved oversight and responsible planning, a P4 Programme officer post is created in RA Kabul.
Considerable analysis has been undertaken in developing staffing recommendations for SO Kandahar, in light of the 2011 VBIED incident. Our recommendation is that one additional international P3 programme/administration officer post be created in Kandahar, bringing the overall international staffing levels to three positions. Two key elements guided the decision-making process regarding international staffing levels. • First, Kandahar is where more than 30% of all conflict-induced displaced originate from or are living in displacement (more than 110,000 IDPs). • Second, within the rule that an international staff should not serve at a hardship duty position alone, and given the four-week rotation cycle, the only two options is either for three international staff or zero international staff.
In addition, and again to ensure harmonization, some national posts have been upgraded, downgraded or re-titled and discontinued. Within the Operating Level (WOL) 27 posts will be created, 13 posts re-classified and 20 posts reduced throughout Afghanistan in 2013. For Above Operating level, an additional three posts are requested, including, Snr Field Coordinator P4, Snr Physical Planner P4 and Telecoms Assistant FS5 intended to support the implementation of the sustainable reintegration strategy and to respond to IDP emergencies. There are in total within the 2013 Within Operating Level plan 351 posts, of which 40 are international and 311 are national.
For ABOD, a total of US$ 11,813,980 is requested within Operating level (OL), representing a slight increase to 2011 expenditures and current 2012 Initial Budget Target for ABOD. This increase is mainly due to the increased security requirements to meet MOSS standards as well as slightly increased rental costs. In addition the operation is proposing discontinuation of 17 G1 positions (cleaners and messengers) and in place would seek to outsource the services through a commercial company. While related staff costs are reduced, additional provision is included within the operating level for the planned outsourcing. It should be noted that the ABOD (WOL) budget includes an allocation of US$ 5.8 million for security budget within the ABOD to meet the requirement of armed guards at all UNHCR Offices and Guesthouses.

The overall security situation in Afghanistan remains volatile, among many components, includes the handing over of military responsibilities from international (ISAF) to national forces (ANA/ANP). Yet while this transition is occurring, the Taliban continue stepping up attacks on military and civilian targets, spreading instability along with its influence further to the north, away from its traditional southern powerbase/ Pashtun traditional strongholds areas.
International Military (IM), Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) and Government of Afghanistan (GOA) relations have been placed under unprecedented strain and public scrutiny with a spring of public relation disasters for the International Military Forces.
The NATO counterinsurgency strategy aimed, in particular, at eliminating the middle management level commanders, seems to have motivated the raise of a new generation of Afghans and Foreigner “middle managers “ who appear to be much more radicalized, without a clear / structured chain of command. Threat reporting continue to indicate the intent of Anti Government(AGE) elements to conduct coordinated attacks and suicide attacks country wide in the attempt to demonstrate the capability to control the tempo.
In this scenario, the threat picture and trends will remain largely unchanged. The pattern of AGE activity will remain similar. Attacks against IM/ANSF will also continue. Provinces in Southern and South East Regions – namely Kunar, Ghazni, Wardak, Paktya, Paktika, Khost, Kandahar and Helmand – will likely remain the most volatile provinces.
In this context, the ability of UNHCR to maintain access and an effective presence will depend on a real- time grasp of local power structures.
