This will require dedicating the necessary means; Soft and Hardware resources to continue acquiring and maintaining a good degree of local contact and knowledge. Strategies and practices, such as “Remote Management Programming” will remain the primary operational approach to enable UNHCR’s delivery capability. The introduction of risk management into programme delivery will continue to support the operation and the partners to better understand the nature and level of risk.
The introduction of Security awareness trainings, and situational awareness adapted to the specific threats in Afghanistan, as a support tool, will help increase confidence and morale.
UNHCR is analysing and documenting where programmes are not lifesaving but of high importance for various other reasons, such as assuring UNHCR long-term strategic goals and securing humanitarian access and maintaining credibility and asylum space with regional partners outside of Afghanistan. This analysis is crucial in defending important activities if an interagency criticality review is eventually conducted, as appears likely, and at all means can help clarify where UNHCR should be focusing efforts in allocating resources and managing risks.
“Acceptance’ approach and “perception” management will enable UNHCR and its partners to better understand its priorities while cultivating good relations with local communities on the ground. Better acceptance will potentially generate access and “vice versa”.
UNHCR will continue to meet the frequent changing MOSS/MORSS (Minimum Operating Security Standards/Minimum Operating Residential Security Standards). This will often entail upgrading of our premises at significant cost, which includes the need to continue deploying international armed guards for static security, as well as providing for our own route of security with the support of the dedicated Afghan National Police, ANP).
Training will remain a high priority and funding will be needed to be allocated for this purpose. The introduction of security awareness trainings, and situational awareness adapted to the specific threats in Afghanistan, is seen as a key support tool to help increase confidence and morale among the staff.

UNHCR Afghanistan enjoyed strong support from its donors with a prominent degree of earmarking at the country level in the previous years. The comparatively high levels of repatriation and increasing necessity to provide appropriate response to the growing internal displacement were the guiding force to the positive funding situation. Key donors appreciate the impact the operation achieves in support of the return of Afghan refugees and their protection and reintegration in the country. They also evaluate positively the efforts to provide support to the internally displaced through appropriate protection activities, material assistance, advocacy and emergency response as well as practical solutions.
UNHCR may put in place a multi-donor Trust Fund or may benefit from a funded UNHCR/UNDP Joint Programme to bridge the gap between relief and development and put in place reintegration in up to 30 high-return reintegration locations. If donor resource mobilization is realized, UNHCR may be able to secure funding for additional activities to help improve return conditions, thereby increasing absorption capacity and creating some pull factors for further refugee return.
UNHCR will also play a catalytic role in favor of Government and donor programmes supporting key locations and sectors absorbing substantial numbers of returning refugees and IDPs. It will use evidence of returnee presence and impact as a key instrument of advocacy. Regular contacts with the main donors in Kabul, notably ECHO, EC, Japan, Denmark, Germany, Belgium, Norway, PRM and others, through individual meetings, donor briefings, weekly updates, funding proposals and periodic progress reports efforts will help fostering a clear understanding of the UNHCR operation in Afghanistan and consolidating the donor base in Kabul.
CAP mechanism led by OCHA and other opportunities as appropriate will also be used to emphasize UNHCR funding requirements. Within the overall operational framework for IDPs, UNHCR will seek to mobilize funding for protection, emergency shelter/NFI as well as for other activities to benefit IDP solutions.

ElementSection.sectionName: IDP's - Overview of the Protection Situation
ElementSection.text:
In 2002, an estimated 1.2 million Afghans were internally displaced. The majority of them returned spontaneously. In 2008, UNHCR profiled the remaining IDP population. According to data from end 2011, there are approximately 450,000 IDPs in Afghanistan, and this indicates an increase of over 185,000 conflict induced IDPs from end 2010. The majority of identified IDPs constitute conflict induced displaced in recent years. It should be noted that UNHCR tracks internal displacement due to the conflict directly, through its partners, and through its established community outreach mechanisms and networks across the country where significant displacements have occurred as a result of conflict between the insurgency and pro-government forces.
UNHCR is the designated cluster lead for Protection and Emergency Shelter and NFIs clusters in Afghanistan. UNHCR also co-leads the National IDP Task Force and the Housing Land and Property Task Force in Afghanistan. The linkages of protection of civilians including refugee returnees, IDPs and other populations of concern with the overall protection situation in Afghanistan is enabled through UNHCR leadership of the Protection cluster.
UNHCR has led the development of a national IDP strategy, which addresses the protracted IDP caseload and has created mechanisms for responding to new displacements. UNHCR has also developed an internal IDP Strategy to standardize and harmonize its work for the internally displaced in Afghanistan and this has been implemented through 2010 and 2011.
Comprehensive protection overview of the country and identification of limitations relating to the protection of vulnerable populations remains a key responsibility of the Afghanistan Protection cluster. This includes gap identification, needs assessments and facilitation of relevant responses by the humanitarian community including for IDPs. UNHCR active and often leadership role in the inter-cluster mechanisms also contributes to these comprehensive efforts.
Discrimination against IDPs exists, but it is generally due to their ethnicity or place of origin in Afghanistan, not their status as IDPs. For example, Pashtun IDPs in the West and North are, in some instances, viewed with suspicion by Tajik and Uzbek residents, who may associate them with elements of the insurgency.
Civilians were severely affected by conflict, not only through deaths, injuries and the pervasive atmosphere of intimidation, but also through displacement, damage and destruction to property, loss of livelihood, lack of freedom of movement and lack of access to essential services such as health care, food and education. The precarious situation of populations in need and displaced persons from insecurity and violence prevented the humanitarian community from accessing these persons and locations, exacerbating the situation of already vulnerable populations. The presence of numerous armed groups also adversely impacted on humanitarian work as the safety of humanitarian workers could not be guaranteed in many areas. Concerns remain about full and consistent implementation by ISAF of the Tactical Directives and procedures on the ground and the persistent lack of transparency on investigations and accountability for civilian casualties which have increased radically and was at its highest since casualty records began in 2007. Continuous review, analysis and evaluation of Tactical Directives and their implementation would further strengthen civilian protection by PGF.

Internal displacement of civilians due to the conflict is addressed through the combined interplay of UNHCR with the line Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation (MoRR) and its regional Offices (DoRRs). UNHCR provides technical and institutional support to the MoRR, which although responsible for developing policies and coordinating actions to protect and assist IDPs, remains limited in its ability and willingness to overcome its institutional and operational weaknesses. This results in UNHCR taking substantive responsibility for IDP identification, data management, reporting and coordination of responses.
UNHCR is the leading agency on coordination of all information and responses to internal displacements related to conflict and persecution whereas IOM has undertaken responsibility for coordination of natural disaster induced displacements although UNHCR remains the protection coordinator for all IDPs irrespective of cause of displacement.
In the absence of any legislative base dedicated to the protection of IDPs, various provisions of international human rights and humanitarian law form part of the normative framework in Afghanistan. The Afghan National Development Strategy referred to the durable solution of those displaced due to the conflict as this government strategy was developed in the backdrop of an improving security and development scenario in Afghanistan. These do not remain directly relevant today due to the currently much needed emphasis on prevention of displacement and speedy protection and assistance response to IDPs.
On a policy level, concerns remain about IDP group flows within conflict zones which are not accessible to the humanitarian community and/ or the Government as well as displacements to mixed urban habitations. Further, the additional mixed nature of many population flows also remains in need of due attention with the absence of urban planning and slum dweller assistance programmes in Afghanistan further complicating the situation. UNHCR has been steering the awareness and lobbying for a national policy on IDPs including on urban displacement. This process includes the engagement of several stakeholders most relevant of which is the line Minister of Refugees and Repatriation (MoRR).
The impact of the Government of Afghanistan launched, Afghan Local Police Programme ALP has played out in recent months. The ALP is envisioned as a Ministry of Interior-led rural security programme to protect communities from the insurgency through the recruitment of local individuals into an armed force that reports to the district chief of police. Reports of ALP as a cause of persecution and displacement continue to flow. UNAMA has reported on this in its 2011 Annual Protection of Civilians Report. There are serious concerns about weak oversight, recruitment, vetting and command and control mechanisms of ALP including limited training for recruits and the effectiveness of reporting through district police chiefs. It is a matter of concern and rigorous oversight and monitoring of all elements of the ALP programme are necessary, to ensure the programme does not result in reduced protection for civilians and further entrench impunity.
UNHCR as the lead of Protection cluster has been leading advocacy on behalf of humanitarian actors on several key issues impacting the protection of civilians.

As such IDPs can freely move within the country to seek protection and assistance besides opportunities for sustainable livelihoods. However, given the complex ethnic and political dynamics in the country and due to the tribal and group societal structures, freedom of movement is limited for IDP groups to areas with ethnic and political proximity. At the same time, individual IDPs and their families have freedom of movement to the larger regional urban areas and to the urban slums in the capital.
While the DoRRs and UNHCR have methods for recording IDP groups, there is no procedure for the registration of IDPs. This has been the case for all non-protracted IDP groups who are known more through their representatives rather than through family or individual registration. It is also pertinent that significant displacements occur within conflict zones; those scattered as individuals or families across the country; or IDPs in urban areas seek shelter with family members or host families or even obtain rented accommodations. These IDPs remain unregistered and unaccounted.
UNHCR conducted a profiling of the known IDP groups in 2008. Subsequent developments on data clarity through the development of internal IDP strategy as well as through data entry tools continue to support UNHCR role in monitoring IDP populations. Additional work has been done to refine regional and national mechanisms to identify new displacements, update and refine existing data, better understand the needs of IDPs, and take concrete action to assist them through the National and Regional IDP Task Forces established by UNHCR in collaboration with MoRR/DoRRs. A Data Harmonization Working Group was also established between the two agencies for improvements in data management and identification of IDPs and this has been implemented through recent months
Prevention, early warning, and emergency response mechanisms need strengthening at regional and national levels especially with increasing incidence of armed conflict in the regions of South, South-East, East, West and the North where more conflict induced displacement is expected. The matter of prevention and mitigation of internal displacement has been raised with ISAF and Government of Afghanistan by UNHCR both bilaterally and as lead of the Protection Cluster. Advocacy on this is undergoing and efforts are being made to establish clarity of IDP policy amongst Pro Government Forces.
Access to individual and civil status documentation is one of the most serious protection problems which IDPs face. Nationally recognized identification is generally required to access education and health services, obtain a passport, acquire a driving license, or qualify for land allocation schemes under Decree 104. Obtaining identification poses particular problems for Kuchis (typically nomadic) who have difficulties establishing their place of origin and, as a general matter, face discrimination.

The attitude of the government undermines IDPs on government owned lands/urban informal settlements (which are visible due to acute poverty and lack of basic facilities) resulting in threats/eviction, and forced relocation. In displacement areas controlled by the insurgency, service delivery barely exists.
The human cost of the armed conflict grew as civilian casualties went up substantially in 2011 compared to 2009 and 2009. In 2011, UNAMA HR documented 3,021 civilian deaths, the highest annual number of civilian deaths ever recorded by UNAMA. In 2011, 77% of all civilian deaths were attributed to AGEs. 410 civilian deaths resulted from the operations of PGF, a decrease of 4% from 2010. In 2011, 14% of civilian deaths were attributed to Pro-Government Forces (PGF), a slight decrease from 2010. A further 279 civilian deaths, or 9% of the total, could not be attributed to either party to the conflict. The notable change in 2011 reported by UNAMA HR, was the change in tactics used by AGE’s with reliance on varied IEDs and deadlier and higher-profile suicide attacks. Civilian deaths through PGF Aerial attacks increased in 2011.
In 2011, women and children again increasingly bore the brunt of the armed conflict. The number of Afghan women and children killed in 2011 increased from 2010, particularly in the second half of 2011. UNAMA HR documented the deaths of 166 women and 306 children, representing 30% of all civilian deaths between July and December 2011. Compared with the same span in 2010, the number of women killed grew by 29% and the number of children killed by 51% in the last half of 2011.
Furthermore, conflict and insecurity displaced 185,632 Afghans in 2011, an increase of 45% from 2010. Thousands more Afghans lost their livelihoods and property, were denied access to justice, had their right to freedom of movement restricted or taken away (armed groups led check points and roads lined with IEDs), and had their access to food, health and education compromised. UNHCR works with the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission (AIHRC) with increased emphasis on understanding the protection needs of IDPs although the AIHRC remains institutionally weak and often is unable to effectively identify violations, follow up, or facilitate remedies. Children face a wide range of protection concerns, including child labor, smuggling/human trafficking, and early or forced marriage. UNHCR responds to these issues through the EVI Project and participation in the Child Protection Network (CPAN). UNHCR is also a member of the MRM Country Task Force-SC Resolution 1612. UNHCR supports the identification and referral of vulnerable children (unaccompanied/ separated/ affected by armed conflict) to CPAN networks, especially relevant in border areas. Violence against women continues to be a deep-rooted problem affecting women/girls from all social/ethnic groups. Their social/economic/political independence is not accepted. UNHCR supports safe houses for women at risk through the UNIFEM-led Trust Fund which finances preventive and responsive mechanisms including research/ capacity building/advocacy/access to justice. Current negative interest by the government on shelters is worrying. UNHCR along with UNFPA and UNICEF launched and implemented an active GBV Capacity Promotion Programme for Afghan Trainers and capacity promoters. UNHCR has carried forward its commitment to disseminate and implement its role across the country, which has been enabled through 2011.
Sharia and customary law coexist with the formal legal system, despite efforts to strengthen the formal justice system. Corruption/inadequate capacity/gender bias negatively affect the judiciary. Shuras/jirgas composed of elders, tribal leaders and mullahs (exclusively men) apply customary codes and in some cases civil law.

Outreach to rural communities, and the construction of a sound relationship with central government structures, has long been one of the key challenges of Afghan state-building. Local power is often concentrated in the hands of a few (landlords, mullahs, tribal elders, local commanders). In rural areas, participation in national political processes is very limited. Urban populations face other challenges, as cities are pushed to the limits of absorption capacity. Growing settlements of squatters, in particular, face significant social, economic and political marginalization, in addition to threats of eviction by the authorities. Special concerns relate to IDP populations mixed with urban squatters living in deplorable conditions. Identification of IDPs from amongst the larger squatter community for any form of assistance or services is challenging and potential for heightened expectations and possible discontent among the non IDP populations. A linked problem relates to the hasty classification of all urban squatters as IDPs. This is especially contentious as most urban squatter sites are prominent and attract media and other attention. The situation is further confounded by the absence of governmental institutions to address urban planning and squatter needs.
Informal governance structures based on family, tribe and ethnic group are quite common, particularly in rural areas. “Shuras” or “jirgas,” composed of respected elders, tribal leaders and mullahs (almost exclusively men) take decisions on community matters such as security, local development, infrastructure and dispute resolution. Although “shuras” promote political and community-based participation, it is usually to the exclusion of women and, in some cases, the landless poor.
AGDM principles and Participatory Assessment tools have been incorporated into protection monitoring and needs assessment activities being conducted by UNHCR with IDP populations. These include not only the main protracted IDP settlements, but also the most recent displacement situations caused by the ongoing armed conflict. UNHCR has also incorporated AGDM principles in its IDP protection training activities being conducted with government agencies (in particular MoRR and DoRRs), as well as partner NGOs. The PA has not yet, however, been mainstreamed into the National and Regional IDP Task Forces (clusters format). UNHCR will continue its efforts to roll out these principles as the Cluster lead. In addition, community outreach strategies for IDPs in urban settings are underway but would need substantial efforts to be fully implemented.
Traditional practices continue to prevent a wider access to IDP women and girls, especially during assessments exercises in remote rural villages and with particular concern on the Western, South-Eastern and Southern regions. In addition, the ongoing armed conflict continues to prevent a more consistent and systematic direct engagement with IDPs, especially in remote rural areas.
Agriculture and animal husbandry are no longer sufficient to sustain a majority of rural families. IDPs in rural areas must, therefore, increasingly adapt to the cash economy and the prevailing labor market, diversifying income-generating strategies. The situation of displacement compounds challenges for IDPs in the fragile Afghan economy, particularly for those who were recently displaced and do not have family, tribe or ethnic group support.

The UNHCR and World Bank Report on urban displacement from mid 2011 identified the specific vulnerabilities relating to IDPs in urban slums of Kabul, Kandahar and Herat. While conflict and insecurity is usually the first reported reason for abandoning a place of origin, economic considerations (such as food security and unemployment) emerged strongly as concurrent driving factors.
Sectoral differences in employment between IDPs and the urban poor are reflected also in the occupation structure. IDP male workers are mainly day laborers (68%), followed by self-employment and private sector salaried jobs (23 and 6%, respectively). In comparison, for the urban poor, self-employment is the most prevalent occupation (49%) followed by daily labor (25%) and public sector salaried jobs (17%). The study further suggests that such labor market disadvantages increase IDPs vulnerability to poverty.
The study also reveals the extreme vulnerability to food insecurity for IDPs living in informal settlements. According to the National Risk and Vulnerability Assessment sample, IDPs food insecurity is much worse than that of urban poor households. Considering extreme outcomes, only 7% of IDPs report to have never faced problems in meeting household food needs versus 37% of the urban poor; on the other hand 14% of IDPs report to be mostly food insecure i.e. to have problems satisfying food needs several times every month – compared with only 3% of the urban poor.
Although progress has been made on the education front since the fall of the Taliban regime in 2001, educational indicators remain among the worst in the world. Afghan girls and women, in particular, face formidable challenges accessing education.
The biggest IDP settlements normally have self-constructed mud brick housing units for IDP families, which are built with UNHCR assistance in some instances. Other IDP communities face serious shelter problems, living in tents and makeshift shelters.

Within the context of the protracted IDP caseload, it is expected that local integration will continue to be the most common durable solution for IDPs. However the challenge remains of obtaining government and local support for this durable solution. Return to the place of origin will likely be the next most common solution. Given the fragile economy and limited absorption capacity in Afghanistan, it is assumed that relocation will continue to be the least likely durable solution for IDPs.
Afghans displaced in the context of the ongoing armed conflict in Afghanistan used to tend to return home spontaneously, shortly after the fighting ended. However this trend has been altered in 2010 and 2011 as witnessed following the nature of the conflict in the South, especially in Helmand and Kandahar provinces. Displacements in the West, East and North have also tended to be longer lasting as compared to the past. In most incidents to enable voluntary return extensive rebuilding and reintegration efforts will be necessary. Special reference is made to the abundance of land mines, booby traps and other IEDs on routes of return and places of origin, thus limiting speedy and spontaneous returns.
Legal, socio-economic, and political obstacles will complicate the achievement of durable solutions for many IDPs. In the context of personal identification and property disputes, legal solutions may be indicated. In view of the limitations of formal and informal dispute resolution systems in Afghanistan, however, political and economic solutions will, in many contexts, be equally or more important. Negotiating increased access to land, for example, will be central to achieving sustainable solutions for IDPs.
The UNHCR and World Bank Report May 2011 on urban displacement in Kandahar, Kabul and Heart identified concrete issues relating to the prospects of durable solutions for IDPs in urban slums. However State disinterest and inaction on follow up to this has been prominent. This has resulted in disinterest and the lack of possible options for IDPs in deplorable living conditions. More than 90 percent of IDPs reported in the WB/ UNHCR study, plans to settle permanently in the city irrespective of the persistence of conflict. About 80 percent were not willing to return to their communities of origin due to the lack of livelihood opportunities (unemployment, land, food insecurity). As a re-sult, humanitarian assistance for immediate needs following conflict induced displacement must be accompanied by long-term develop-ment interventions that promote sustainable integration of IDPs who intend to settle permanently in their current locations.
In the wake of profiling protracted IDP settlements in Herat, Kandahar and Helmand provinces, over 4,000 IDPs had voluntarily returned from the South to their places of origin in 2010, primarily in the North. However the conflict has moved to those locations rendering them further vulnerable. In the West, efforts to locally integrate protracted IDP populations are ongoing but are made contentious due to the increased value of the government and private lands on which the protracted IDP settlements are located. New displacements in the West and East including the South East and especially in the North, due to active conflict has resulted in significant new displacements through 2010 and 2011 rendering durable solutions difficult.
UNHCR has lead of the National IDP TF and the Protection cluster urges the State and other stakeholders to actively consider the durable solutions of all IDPs, especially those in protracted displacement and those in deplorable conditions in urban settlements.

ElementSection.sectionName: Stateless - Overview of the Protection Situation

ElementSection.text:
The Government of Afghanistan will be looking towards the planned presidential election in 2014. Negotiations with the Taliban commenced during 2011, possibly to identify an agreement that would result in a significant reduction in the threats and overt acts of violence. The negotiations are confidential; however, media reports indicate uneven progress and dialogue.
The last census was carried out in 1978, however the current population is estimated at between 25-31 million people. The CSO of the Government of Afghanistan estimates that 50% of the population lives below the poverty line, and another 30% are precariously close to it. The urban population is estimated at around 23%, the majority living in rural areas, though urbanization is growing at an estimated 5% annually. More than 50% of the population is estimated to be illiterate.
Afghanistan continues to have significant humanitarian concerns, further exacerbated by an ineffective development agenda implementation. Afghans, living in or precariously close to the poverty line are frequently at risk of natural disasters and further economic setbacks. The 2011 Consolidated Appeal humanitarian priority objectives:
1. Plan for and respond to the humanitarian aid and protection needs arising from armed conflict, particularly: the displaced; those without access to basic assistance; and populations where there is no humanitarian access. 2. Protection and initial return assistance to IDPs and refugee returnees. 3. Prepare for and respond to the protection and humanitarian needs arising from annual and seasonal natural 'disasters' and advocacy for progress on implementation of Hyogo Framework Priorities 1-4. 4. Advocate protection support and appropriate development interventions to acutely vulnerable populations targeted by the MDGs, whether in rural or urban areas.
In the absence of trusted political leaders, the security situation continues to worsen. The Taliban frequently asks for Afghans to fight against the Government of Afghanistan, international military troops and westerners in general.
ISAF began handing over security responsibility to the Government of Afghanistan security officials, including the Afghan Army, Police and Security Directorate in 2011. This hand-over of security responsibilities will increase and are scheduled to be completed by June 2013.
The security situation has not improved with the security hand-over, nor has the security situation deteriorated significantly. Nonetheless, UNHCR and the UN do not have direct humanitarian access to some 50 per cent of Afghanistan. There are concerns about recent developments on arming of militias and ‘arbakai’ as well as Afghan Local Police (ALP).
UNHCR foresees possible security clashes which may lead to displacement especially in the East, South, Southeast and the North of Afghanistan. The displacement may be caused by territorial disputes between the Taliban and the Afghan security forces, Taliban efforts to intimidate and occupy certain areas, flare up of tribal disputes and consequences of surgical international military interventions.
The Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS) objectives’ are being transposed into the National Priority Programmes (NPPs) pursuant to the 2009 Kabul process. Of the 23 NPPs, 13 are considered to be relevant to UNHCR’s people of concern. UNHCR is engaging with respective line ministries to ensure that high-return areas are among the priorities for NPP programming. NPPs of particular relevance include livelihood, education and justice, merging a top-down planning government process with a grass-roots approach to improve the situation of returning refugees and other community members.
Internal displacement increased 45% between 2010 and 2011, and the trend is expected to remain constant in 2012, with a planning figure of 150,000 displaced and 50,000 people to find solutions.

In the recent years, UNHCR focused its operational efforts on supporting the voluntary repatriation and providing initial reintegration assistance, providing emergency assistance to those in a refugee-like situation, asylum-seekers and pursuing durable solutions for a small refugee caseload. UNHCR also engaged in efforts to be a catalyst to ensure development efforts mainstreamed refugee returnees to support their reintegration. UNHCR, as the cluster lead for the shelter and protection cluster, monitored the growing numbers of people internally displaced, provided emergency assistance through a coordinated approach and pursued protection strategies to address their needs, including to pursue spontaneous and facilitated solutions. In 2011:
• Nearly 68,000 refugees voluntarily repatriated to Afghanistan under the auspices of the UNHCR voluntary repatriation programme, bringing the voluntary repatriation to 4.6 million returnees since 2002. UNHCR offered grants to cover returning refugees’ transport and meet initial return needs, especially for the most vulnerable. Returning refugees are processed through voluntary repatriation centres in countries of asylum and upon return to ensure that their decision is voluntary and well-informed, and provided health, social, mine risk and legal counseling.
• UNHCR actively engaged through a regional approach with the Governments of Pakistan, Islamic Republic of Iran and Afghanistan in preparation of an international conference planned for 2012. Through a series of preparatory meetings, a Comprehensive Solutions Strategy is emerging which will focus on supporting Voluntary Repatriation, Sustainable Reintegration and assistance to host countries.
• UNHCR launched a pilot project to support sustainable reintegration in seven pilot reintegration sites in high-return areas. The pilot methodology provides multi-sectoral community-based assistance, with the aim to help refugee returnees achieve parity with other community members in terms of access to basic services such as health, education and water, livelihood, protection and shelter. An impact analysis of this approach is underway and will be delivered in 2012.
• Internal displacement increased sharply during 2011, with an estimated 201,817 people internally displaced, bringing the total of IDPs to more than 447,500 people. However, some 75,000 IDPs were able to find solutions, to have locally integrated, relocated or spontaneously returned to their homes, though it is not known how sustainable the solutions may be. UNHCR, as the protection and shelter/NFI lead, is working to coordinate emergency NFI assistance, track the population movements and identify IDP protection and assistance needs.
• UNHCR strengthened its information collection mechanisms for IDPs especially those newly displaced across the country. This was possible through establishment of active networks amongst implementing and operational partners across provinces most prone to conflicts. UNHCR IDP data and protection information including gaps and needs is a key source for the entire humanitarian community and for overall humanitarian coordination. The process of furthering networks and piloting technical methods of real- time information gathering and response is currently underway.
• More than 3,000 people are in a refugee-like situation, having fled violence in their home country to Afghanistan due to cross-border shelling. Immediate emergency response was provided including NFI kits and winterized items, such as warm clothing and fuel.
• The Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation are in the process of drafting national refugee legislation. The number of refugees in Afghanistan is modest, but growing, and the Office is seeking opportunities to promote protection-sensitive entry procedures as well as improve reception conditions.

Returning refugees
Since 2002, UNHCR assisted 4.6 million refugees to return to Afghanistan through the provision of voluntary repatriation grants. In 2011, the number of returning refugees was nearly 68,000 people. In total, more than 5.7 million people are believed to have returned in the last ten years. Refugees surveyed in Pakistan cited security and economic concerns as the two biggest reasons for their continued stay in exile.
For 2013 UNHCR estimates 172,000 refugees will return, including 150,000 from Pakistan and 20,000 from Iran. This takes into account the lowered return figures of 2011 as well as the increasing asylum fatigue in Iran and Pakistan, where authorities have stated that voluntary repatriation is the primary solution for the some 2.7 million refugees. The registration of Afghans in Pakistan is due to expire on December 2012, after which it is not yet clear what status refugees will have.
UNHCR conducted a Community Snapshot Survey in 2011, which found that a significant number of community and returnee leaders considered that returnees are less integrated than other community members. The study also found that some 15% of returnees moved from their place of origin, usually to urban centres or abroad, often in search of economic livelihood or food security.
The security situation as well as lack of funds has prevented UNHCR to systematically monitor the return and reintegration of returnees. Hence, comprehensive and systematic data with regard to the whereabouts of returnees and the extent of their integration is lacking. Furthermore, a significant number of refugees have returned and live in an IDP-like situation.
Asylum-seekers, refugees and people in a refugee-like situation
Asylum-seekers and refugees in Afghanistan number less than 125 persons. In addition, more than 3,000 people are considered to be living in a refugee-like situation, having been displaced from their homes across international borders. UNHCR is increasingly engaged in the drafting of refugee legislation as well as commencing protection activities to improve reception conditions and ensure protection-aware border policies and implementation practices. In the interim, however, UNHCR continues with providing assistance to refugees and asylum-seekers to address material needs. While the number of refugees/asylum-seekers is expected to remain constant in 2012 and in 2013, the number of people living in a refugee-like situation is expected to increase in 2012 by some 3,000 people a year.
Conflict-induced IDPs
The number of IDPs as of end-December 2011 was 447,500 IDPs, an increase of 45% between 2010 and 2011. During 2011, some 75,000 IDPs found solutions or were no longer in their place of displacement. For 2012, the conflict-induced planning figure is 150,000 people, and an estimated 50,000 will find solutions, bringing the 2012 year-end project to 547,500.
For 2013, given the potential upheaval linked to elections, transfer of security responsibilities and social tensions, the planning figure for conflict-induced IDPs is 200,000 people, with an estimated 47,000 persons finding solutions. By end-2013, the planning figure for conflict-induced IDPs is 700,000.
For IDPs, UNHCR acknowledges that improved coordination is required to track population movements, understand and address the root causes of the displacement. UNHCR will pursue a more coordinated effort to facilitate spontaneous as well as assisted solutions, be in local integration, relocation or return.
Protection support and emergency assistance has and will be provided as required by the circumstances of the displacement situation, pending access. In addition, UNHCR will continue to explore possible durable solutions, primarily voluntary return to the place of origin or integration in their place of displacement.

With more than 2.7 million refugees in the neighboring countries, UNHCR’s work in Afghanistan can only be effectively pursued through regular regional processes, partnerships and agreements. In the preparation for the international conference expected in 2012, three preparatory meetings were convened, and included government counterparts from Afghanistan, Pakistan and the Islamic Republic of Iran. The meetings provided a positive momentum for agreeing on a Comprehensive Solutions Strategy to addressing the challenges of Afghan refugees and returnees. These series of meetings will culminate in an international conference planned for the first part of 2012. It is foreseen that the follow-up of the International Conference will be bi-annual quadripartite meetings, with the participation of the Governments of Afghanistan, Pakistan and Iran as well as UNHCR. The meetings are expected to discuss the comprehensive solutions strategy including voluntary repatriation, sustainable reintegration and assistance to host governments.
It is not yet known if the quadpartite biannual meetings will replace the regular meetings of the Tripartite Agreements on voluntary return and its supporting Tripartite Commission.
Though not directly of UNHCR’s concern, the Office UNHCR will continue to closely follow developments related to alternative stay arrangements and modalities offered by Pakistan and the Islamic Republic of Iran to refugees as well as economic migrants residing in the respective countries.
During 2012 and 2013, it is expected that there will be four regional internal UNHCR meetings with UNHCR Iran and Pakistan to discuss various programmatic, operational and protection matters.
